		<div class="content">
			<h2 class="river__title river__title--home">The Latest</h2>
			<div class="river river--homepage">
				<div class="post-block post-block--image post-block--unread">
	<header class="post-block__header">
		<h2 class="post-block__title">

		</h2>
		<div class="post-block__meta">

<script type="text/javascript" id="tc-app-js-extra">
/* <![CDATA[ */
var tc_app_data = {"ads":{"gemini_enabled":false,"gemini_codes":{"position_4":{"mobile":"ae64471c-14c2-4457-8e9b-a5190206eafd","desktop":"b2018d9e-dedc-4e85-8823-b06917beb892"},"position_8":{"mobile":"619392a1-b497-4aa9-b683-24aab7246c16","desktop":"05c0b21d-e742-494d-ac59-474e3feaa4b8"}}},"assetURI":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/themes\/techcrunch-2017","breaking":"0","live_event":"0","livestream":"","feature_islands":{"homepage":[{"id":2665704,"date":"2024-02-17T07:24:19","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T15:24:19","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2665704"},"modified":"2024-02-17T07:24:19","modified_gmt":"2024-02-17T15:24:19","slug":"women-in-ai-irene-solaiman-head-of-global-policy-at-hugging-face","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/women-in-ai-irene-solaiman-head-of-global-policy-at-hugging-face\/","title":{"rendered":"Women In AI: Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">series of interviews<\/a> focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more profiles <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Irene Solaiman began her career in AI as a researcher and public policy manager at OpenAI, where she led a new approach to the release of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/02\/17\/openai-text-generator-dangerous\/\">GPT-2<\/a>, a predecessor to ChatGPT. After serving as an AI policy manager at Zillow for nearly a year, she joined Hugging Face as the head of global policy. Her responsibilities there range from building and leading company AI policy globally to conducting socio-technical research.<\/p>\n<p>Solaiman also advises the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), the professional association for electronics engineering, on AI issues, and is a recognized AI expert at the intergovernmental Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).<\/p>\n<h2>Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face<\/h2>\n<h3>Briefly, how did you get your start in AI? What attracted you to the field?<\/h3>\n<p>A thoroughly nonlinear career path is commonplace in AI. My budding interest started in the same way many teenagers with awkward social skills find their passions: through sci-fi media. I originally studied human rights policy and then took computer science courses, as I viewed AI as a means of working on human rights and building a better future. Being able to do technical research and lead policy in a field with so many unanswered questions and untaken paths keeps my work exciting.<\/p>\n<h3>What work are you most proud of (in the AI field)?<\/h3>\n<p>I\u2019m most proud of when my expertise resonates with people across the AI field, especially my writing on release considerations in the complex landscape of AI system releases and openness. Seeing my paper on an <a href=\"https:\/\/arxiv.org\/pdf\/2302.04844.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AI Release Gradient frame technical deployment<\/a> prompt discussions among scientists and used in government reports is affirming &#8212; and a good sign I\u2019m working in the right direction! Personally, some of the work I\u2019m most motivated by is on cultural value alignment, which is dedicated to ensuring that systems work best for the cultures in which they&#8217;re deployed. With my incredible co-author and now dear friend, Christy Dennison, working on a <a href=\"https:\/\/arxiv.org\/pdf\/2106.10328.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Process for Adapting Language Models to Society<\/a> was a whole of heart (and many debugging hours) project that has shaped safety and alignment work today.<\/p>\n<h3>How do you navigate the challenges of the male-dominated tech industry, and, by extension, the male-dominated AI industry?<\/h3>\n<p>I\u2019ve found, and am still finding, my people &#8212; from working with incredible company leadership who care deeply about the same issues that I prioritize to great research co-authors with whom I can start every working session with a mini therapy session. Affinity groups are hugely helpful in building community and sharing tips. Intersectionality is important to highlight here; my communities of Muslim and BIPOC researchers are continually inspiring.<\/p>\n<h3>What advice would you give to women seeking to enter the AI field?<\/h3>\n<p>Have a support group whose success is your success. In youth terms, I believe this is a &#8220;girl\u2019s girl.&#8221; The same women and allies I entered this field with are my favorite coffee dates and late-night panicked calls ahead of a deadline. One of the best pieces of career advice I\u2019ve read was from Arvind Narayan on the platform formerly known as Twitter establishing the &#8220;Liam Neeson Principle&#8221;of not being the smartest of them all, but having a particular set of skills.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<h3>What are some of the most pressing issues facing AI as it evolves?<\/h3>\n<p>The most pressing issues themselves evolve, so the meta answer is: International coordination for safer systems for all peoples. Peoples who use and are affected by systems, even in the same country, have varying preferences and ideas of what is safest for themselves. And the issues that arise will depend not only on how AI evolves, but on the environment into which they&#8217;re deployed; safety priorities and our definitions of capability differ regionally, such as a higher threat of cyberattacks to critical infrastructure in more digitized economies.<\/p>\n<h3>What are some issues AI users should be aware of?<\/h3>\n<p>Technical solutions rarely, if ever, address risks and harms holistically. While there are steps users can take to increase their AI literacy, it\u2019s important to invest in a multitude of safeguards for risks as they evolve. For example, I\u2019m excited about more research into watermarking as a technical tool, and we also need coordinated policymaker guidance on generated content distribution, especially on social media platforms.<\/p>\n<h3>What is the best way to responsibly build AI?<\/h3>\n<p>With the peoples affected and constantly re-evaluating our methods for assessing and implementing safety techniques. Both beneficial applications and potential harms constantly evolve and require iterative feedback. The means by which we improve AI safety should be collectively examined as a field. The most popular evaluations for models in 2024 are much more robust than those I was running in 2019. Today, I\u2019m much more bullish about technical evaluations than I am about red-teaming. I find human evaluations extremely high utility, but as more evidence arises of the mental burden and disparate costs of human feedback, I\u2019m increasingly bullish about standardizing evaluations.<\/p>\n<h3>How can investors better push for responsible AI?<\/h3>\n<p>They already are! I\u2019m glad to see many investors and venture capital companies actively engaging in safety and policy conversations, including via open letters and Congressional testimonies. I\u2019m eager to hear more from investors\u2019 expertise on what stimulates small businesses across sectors, especially as we\u2019re seeing more AI use from fields outside the core tech industries.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a series of interviews focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577231038"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577231038"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666502,"date":"2024-02-17T05:00:10","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T13:00:10","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666502"},"modified":"2024-02-16T11:08:51","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T19:08:51","slug":"why-ransomware-makes-so-much-money","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/why-ransomware-makes-so-much-money\/","title":{"rendered":"Why are ransomware gangs making so much money?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">For many organizations<\/span> and startups, 2023 was a rough year financially, with companies struggling to raise money and others making cuts to survive. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ransomware and extortion gangs<\/a>, on the other hand, had a record-breaking year in earnings, if recent reports are anything to go by.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s hardly surprising when you look at the state of the ransomware landscape. Last year saw hackers continue to evolve their tactics to become scrappier and more extreme in efforts to pressure victims into paying their increasingly exorbitant ransom demands. This escalation in tactics, along with the fact that governments have stopped short of banning ransom payments, led to 2023 becoming the most lucrative year yet for ransomware gangs.<\/p>\n<h2>The billion-dollar cybercrime business<\/h2>\n<p>According to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.chainalysis.com\/blog\/ransomware-2024\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">new data from crypto forensics startup Chainalysis<\/a>, known ransomware payments almost doubled in 2023 to surpass the $1 billion mark, calling the year a \u201cmajor comeback for ransomware.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s the highest figure ever observed, and almost double the amount of known ransom payments tracked in 2022. But Chainalysis said the actual figure is likely far higher than the $1.1 billion in ransom payments it has witnessed so far.<\/p>\n<p>There\u2019s a glimmer of good news, though. While 2023 was overall a bumper year for ransomware gangs, other <a href=\"https:\/\/www.coveware.com\/blog\/2024\/1\/25\/new-ransomware-reporting-requirements-kick-in-as-victims-increasingly-avoid-paying\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hacker-watchers observed a drop in payments<\/a> toward the end of the year.<\/p>\n<p>This drop is a result of improved cyber defenses and resiliency, along with the growing sentiment that most victim organizations don&#8217;t trust hackers to keep their promises or delete any stolen data as they claim. \u201cThis has led to better guidance to victims and fewer payments for intangible assurances,\u201d according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.coveware.com\/blog\/2024\/1\/25\/new-ransomware-reporting-requirements-kick-in-as-victims-increasingly-avoid-paying\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ransomware remediation company Coveware<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h2>Record-breaking ransoms<\/h2>\n<p>While more ransomware victims are refusing to line the pockets of hackers, ransomware gangs are compensating for this drop in earnings by increasing the number of victims they target.<\/p>\n<p>Take the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/25\/moveit-mass-hack-by-the-numbers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">MOVEit campaign<\/a>. This huge hack saw the prolific Russia-linked Clop ransomware gang mass-exploit a never-before-seen vulnerability in the widely used MOVEit Transfer software to steal data from the systems of more than 2,700 victim organizations. Many of the victims are known to have paid the hacking group in efforts to prevent the publication of sensitive data.<\/p>\n<p>While it\u2019s impossible to know exactly how much money the mass-hack made for the ransomware group, Chainalysis said in its report that Clop&#8217;s MOVEit campaign amassed over $100 million in ransom payments, and accounted for almost half of all ransomware value received in June and July 2023 during the height of this mass-hack.<\/p>\n<p>MOVEit was by no means the only money-making campaign of 2023.<\/p>\n<p>In September, casino and entertainment giant <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/caesars-entertainment-data-breach-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Caesars paid roughly $15 million<\/a> to hackers to prevent the disclosure of customer data stolen during an August cyberattack.<\/p>\n<p>This multimillion-dollar payment perhaps illustrates why ransomware actors continue to make so much money: the Caesars attack barely made it into the news, while a subsequent <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/mgm-cyberattack-outage-scattered-spider\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attack on hotel giant MGM Resorts<\/a> \u2014 which has so far cost the company $100 million to recover from \u2014 dominated headlines for weeks. MGM\u2019s refusal to pay the ransom led to the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/mgm-resorts-admits-hackers-stole-customers-personal-data-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hackers&#8217; release of sensitive MGM customer data<\/a>, including names, Social Security numbers and passport details. Caesars \u2014 outwardly at least \u2014 appeared largely unscathed, even if by its own admission <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/caesars-entertainment-data-breach-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">could not guarantee that the ransomware gang would delete<\/a> the company&#8217;s stolen data.<\/p>\n<h2>Escalating threats<\/h2>\n<p>For many organizations, like Caesars, paying the ransom demand seems like the easiest option to avoid a public relations nightmare. But as the ransom money dries up, ransomware and extortion gangs are upping the ante and resorting to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">escalating tactics and extreme threats<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>In December, for example, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.databreaches.net\/recent-attacks-on-fred-hutch-and-integris-is-attempting-to-extort-patients-directly-becoming-the-new-normal\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hackers reportedly tried to pressure a cancer hospital into paying a ransom demand<\/a> by threatening to &#8220;swat&#8221; its patients. Swatting incidents rely on malicious callers falsely claiming a fake real-world threat to life, prompting the response of armed police officers.<\/p>\n<p>We also saw the notorious Alphv (known as BlackCat) ransomware gang <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/new-sec-data-breach-disclosure-rules\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">weaponize the U.S. government\u2019s new data breach disclosure rules<\/a> against MeridianLink, one of the gang&#8217;s many victims. Alphv accused MeridianLink of allegedly failing to publicly disclose what the gang called \u201ca significant breach compromising customer data and operational information,\u201d for which the gang took credit.<\/p>\n<h2>No ban on ransom payments<\/h2>\n<p>Another reason ransomware continues to be lucrative for hackers is that while not advised, there&#8217;s nothing stopping organizations paying up \u2014 unless, of course, the hackers <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/11\/02\/government-sanctions-ransomware-effective\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">have been sanctioned<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">To pay or not to pay the ransom<\/a> is a controversial subject. Ransomware remediator Coveware suggests that if a ransom payment ban was imposed in the U.S. or any other highly victimized country, companies would likely stop reporting these incidents to the authorities, reversing past cooperation between victims and law enforcement agencies. The company also predicts that a ransom payments ban would lead to the overnight creation of a large illegal market for facilitating ransomware payments.<\/p>\n<p>Others, however, believe a blanket ban is the only way to ensure ransomware hackers can\u2019t continue to line their pockets \u2014 at least in the short term.<\/p>\n<p>Allan Liska, a threat intelligence analyst at Recorded Future, has long opposed banning ransom payments \u2014 but now believes that for as long as ransom payments remain lawful, cybercriminals will do whatever it takes to collect them.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019ve resisted the idea of blanket bans on ransom payments for years, but I think that has to change,&#8221; Liska told TechCrunch. &#8220;Ransomware is getting worse, not just in the number of attacks but in the aggressive nature of the attacks and the groups behind them.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>\u201cA ban on ransom payments will be painful and, if history is any guide, will likely lead to a short-term increase in ransomware attacks, but it seems like this is the only solution that has a chance of long-term success at this point,\u201d said Liska.<\/p>\n<p>While more victims are realizing that paying the hackers cannot guarantee the safety of their data, it\u2019s clear that these financially motivated cybercriminals <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/03\/fbi-most-wanted-russian-hacker-reveals-why-he-burned-his-passport\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">aren&#8217;t giving up their lavish lifestyles anytime soon<\/a>. Until then, ransomware attacks will remain a major money-making exercise for the hackers behind them.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Read more on TechCrunch:<\/strong><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Why ransomware victims can\u2019t stop paying off hackers<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/11\/02\/government-sanctions-ransomware-effective\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Do government sanctions against ransomware groups work?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Why extortion is the new ransomware threat<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>For many organizations and startups, 2023 was a rough year financially, with companies struggling to raise money and others making cuts to survive. Ransomware and extortion gangs, on the other hand, had a record-breaking year in earnings, if recent reports are anything to go by. It&#8217;s hardly surprising when you look at the state of {"rendered":"Y Combinator wants 100 times more MRI scans"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>L<\/em><br \/>\n<em>everaging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. This is good news: We need more companies attacking cancer from novel angles, including AI-enabled early detection. And who knows, maybe one of these will become a trillion-dollar company? \u2014 <\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/abracarioca\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><i>Anna<\/i><\/a><\/p>\n<h2>Scaling early cancer detection<\/h2>\n<p><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Y Combinator&#8217;s newest<\/span> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.ycombinator.com\/blog\/ycs-latest-request-for-startups\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">request for startups<\/a> (RFS) is well worth reading, and not just because it&#8217;s been a while since the incubator shared the ideas and categories its partners &#8220;would like to see more people working on.&#8221; As my colleague Sarah Perez noted, YC hadn&#8217;t updated its full list <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/\">since 2018<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"13H8g1hAa5\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/\">Y Combinator puts out a new call for startups in areas like AI, spatial computing, climate tech and more<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Y Combinator puts out a new call for startups in areas like AI, spatial computing, climate tech and more&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/embed\/#?secret=67NfdoNE3x#?secret=13H8g1hAa5\" data-secret=\"13H8g1hAa5\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Taken as a whole, YC&#8217;s RFS is a great way to sense the zeitgeist; the list includes AI of course, as well as climate tech, defense tech and more. But zooming in on individual requests is also a worthwhile exercise.<\/p>\n<p>One of the requests that captured my interest calls for &#8220;<a href=\"https:\/\/www.ycombinator.com\/rfs#a-way-to-end-cancer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a way to end cancer<\/a>.&#8221; Written by YC group partner Surbhi Sarna, a former medical device company CEO, it focuses on MRIs. &#8220;Since most cancers are now treatable if caught early enough,&#8221; she wrote, &#8220;this technology would dramatically reduce cancer deaths if rolled out widely and affordably.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>My first thought was that MRI startups already exist. Just a few days earlier, New York\u2013based Ezra raised a fresh round of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/rashishrivastava\/2024\/02\/10\/meet-the-bryan-johnson-approved-ai-full-body-mri-startup-that-just-raised-21-million\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$21 million<\/a> \u2014 and we are talking about a team that TechCrunch first covered <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/15\/ezra-cancer\/\">in 2018<\/a>. It has competitors, too, such as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/neko-health\/\">Neko<\/a>, backed by Spotify&#8217;s Daniel Ek, and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prenuvo.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Prenuvo<\/a>, which has a $2,500 full-body scan that was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/anafaguy\/2023\/08\/10\/kim-kardashian-promotes-2500-body-scan-heres-what-to-know-and-why-some-experts-warn-against-it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">promoted by Kim Kardashian<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>For Sarna, that price point is part of the problem, as it inherently limits scale, but it&#8217;s not the only one. &#8220;There is backlash from the medical community as MRIs also create incidental findings (or false positives) that cost our healthcare system valuable time and money to investigate.&#8221; The jury is <a href=\"https:\/\/english.elpais.com\/health\/2023-11-12\/mris-for-no-reason-the-health-debate-unleashed-by-kim-kardashian.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">still<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.newyorker.com\/science\/annals-of-medicine\/will-a-full-body-mri-scan-help-you-or-hurt-you\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">out<\/a> on whether they are beneficial or individuals, let alone society. But YC still hopes startups can help.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"IotSs5Vqf7\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/27\/how-to-get-into-y-combinator-dalton-caldwell\/\">How to get into Y Combinator, according to YC&#8217;s Dalton Caldwell<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;How to get into Y Combinator, according to YC&#8217;s Dalton Caldwell&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/27\/how-to-get-into-y-combinator-dalton-caldwell\/embed\/#?secret=TEqKwhxYdD#?secret=IotSs5Vqf7\" data-secret=\"IotSs5Vqf7\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;For this to work, the world would need to scale up the number of MRI scans it does by at least 100x. Doing that will require innovations in the MRI hardware, the AI algorithms to interpret scans and reduce false positives, and the business models and consumer marketing to make it a viable business.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Of course, companies like Ezra are also hoping to do some of this in-house. In its latest <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/pitch-deck-ezra-raise-vc-funding-ai-powered-mri-scans-2024-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pitch deck<\/a>, the startup boasted it &#8220;leverages Al at every step of the screening process.&#8221; But if others can contribute from other angles, I can see why YC would be interested \u2014 I am.<\/p>\n<h2>Co-working for biotech<\/h2>\n<p>Shared lab spaces have been a game changer for biotech startups, Nature <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nature.com\/articles\/d41586-024-00242-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a>. Of course, co-working isn&#8217;t new, but co-working labs provide their customers with much more than office space, saving them both time and money.<\/p>\n<p>This reminded me of Startup Battlefield alum <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/20\/parallel-health-takes-a-biotech-forward-approach-to-skincare-with-custom-phage-therapy\/\">Parallel Health<\/a> \u2014 its chief scientist officer Nathan Brown had mentioned shared labs in passing when we chatted at Disrupt. I noticed he had <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/johannesfruehauf?miniProfileUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_profile%3AACoAAADoJZkBAvPk1U07nSoBS9UlgFyU9fLsaWI\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">liked<\/a> a repost of Nature&#8217;s article, so I asked him for his thoughts. He confirmed that the skincare startup he co-founded had been using <a href=\"https:\/\/www.biolabs.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">BioLabs<\/a>&#8216; shared facilities in Los Angeles, and he highlighted some of the benefits of this concept:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>BioLabs has enabled us to cost-effectively build a consumer biotech product. They make the laboratory infrastructure available to us without having to spend our entire seed round on capital expenses like DNA sequencing machines, laminar flow hoods, and lab-grade freezers. We also save immense amounts of time at BioLabs, because they manage all aspects of environmental health and safety as well as infrastructure management. Maybe most importantly, they create a thriving culture of innovation where startups can collaborate easily and learn from each other.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>While this may read as a local endorsement, startups don&#8217;t have to be based in California to leverage this trend. BioLabs itself is a franchise that has expanded to a dozen locations, and similar things could likely be said of many competing facilities around the world. However, a founder interviewed by Nature, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.accurehealth.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Accure Health<\/a> CEO Jessica Sang, shared a word of caution: Some labs are better equipped and wider-ranging than others. &#8220;If you\u2019re thinking about starting a company, try to visit a few just to see which one is the best.&#8221;<\/p>\n<h2>Virtual data rooms<\/h2>\n<p>Virtual data rooms are another important resource for biotech startups. Calling them &#8220;the unsung hero of biotech financing,&#8221; and noting that they can also be helpful in business development talks, a16z published a <a href=\"https:\/\/a16z.com\/virtual-data-rooms-the-unsung-hero-of-biotech-financing\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">guide<\/a> on what biotech teams should and shouldn&#8217;t put in their data rooms.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Leveraging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. This is good news: We need more companies attacking cancer from novel angles.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574450,"featured_media":2562690,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"4d5c5bec-ae35-3bf8-af99-284ce6218c33","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"","apple_news_api_id":"","apple_news_api_modified_at":"","apple_news_api_revision":"","apple_news_api_share_url":"","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577030454,20429],"tags":[576715346,35186,577189240,576936589,576765839,66455],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796356],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>Y Combinator wants 100 times more MRI scans | TechCrunch<\/title>\n<meta name=\"description\" content=\"Leveraging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[]]}},{"id":2666950,"date":"2024-02-16T22:12:36","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T06:12:36","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666950"},"modified":"2024-02-17T13:16:16","modified_gmt":"2024-02-17T21:16:16","slug":"a-peek-at-how-things-work-today-inside-alphabets-7-billion-growth-stage-investing-arm-capitalg","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/a-peek-at-how-things-work-today-inside-alphabets-7-billion-growth-stage-investing-arm-capitalg\/","title":{"rendered":"A peek inside Alphabet&#8217;s $7 billion growth-stage investing arm, CapitalG"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Almost a year ago, Alphabet\u2019s growth stage venture arm, <a href=\"https:\/\/capitalg.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CapitalG<\/a>, named partner Laela Sturdy as its new head, just as the unit&#8217;s founder, David Lawee, stepped down.<\/p>\n<p>Few were surprised Sturdy was promoted to the post. She joined Google in 2007 in a marketing role, was pulled into a number of departments in the following years, and when CapitalG was launched in 2013, she was recruited by Lawlee, who told CNBC in 2021, &#8220;I kind of made it a point to know who all the stars were inside of Google, and Laela\u2019s name came up a lot.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Of course, for many investors, the last year has been among the toughest in their career. We wondered if the same is true for Sturdy, a former college basketball star who is quick to note that 60% of her team comes from diverse or underrepresented backgrounds. To find out more, we reached her earlier this week at CapitalG&#8217;s bright, airy office in San Francisco&#8217;s Ferry Building; excerpts of our chat are edited lightly for length and clarity below.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Belated congratulations on taking over the helm. How does your management style differ from that of your predecessor, David?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I&#8217;m still leading investments and still on a bunch of boards, but I&#8217;ve loved being able to also put increasing attention on the team and figure out how we can continue to build out the firm. There&#8217;s [now] many more incredible investors that we have at CapitalG.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You have around 50 people on your team; how many of these are investors versus otherwise?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Our model is to find ways that Google and Alphabet can help our portfolio companies, so not only the individuals on this team, but to give you an idea [of what I mean], over the last couple of years, we&#8217;ve had over 3500 different senior advisors inside of Alphabet help partner with our portfolio companies [to help with] pricing analysis, scaling infrastructure, marketing and setting up sales incentives. There are all these different technical and business questions that come up for growth-stage companies, which is where we specialize.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><strong>Access to 3500 different senior advisors! How does that work?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>An example is over the last couple of years, we\u2019ve partnered with the Google training team who does AI and ML training for Google engineers. We said \u2018Hey, this training is really effective and gets really high ratings internally.\u2019 And we have a lot of our portfolio companies asking us, \u2018How can we up level the talent of our engineering and our organizations and get them ready to fully take advantage of the trends in AI?\u2019 So we partnered with the training team and got our portfolio companies access to the exact same training, and we\u2019ve now had hundreds of engineers inside our portfolio go through that training. I worked at Google for a long time before I came to CapitalG, and one of the amazing things about the culture of Google from the beginning is a real culture of knowledge sharing.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The market for AI talent is so competitive. What can you tell portfolio companies that might feel nervous about the information that&#8217;s going into and out of Alphabet through you?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Everything is opt-in from the portfolio companies\u2019 standpoint. We don&#8217;t share anything; we operate totally separately. We don&#8217;t share any portfolio company data with Alphabet and we don&#8217;t share any Alphabet data back to the portfolio companies. We exist as the intermediary to find win-wins where they exist.<\/p>\n<p>As an example, [Google Cloud] has been an incredible go-to-market partner [and] all the other cloud providers are also important and great partners, so we don\u2019t push anything on anyone. We help facilitate the right introductions and marketing partnerships and product discussions where it&#8217;s relevant.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How are decisions made inside CapitalG? Do you have final say over who sees a check?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We have an investment committee [composed of] myself and three other general partners who are really incredible investors. For example, my partner Gene Frantz, who I&#8217;ve been working with for the last 10 years \u2013 since almost the beginning of CapitalG \u2013 is a longtime investor who was at TPG and other places before [joining the outfit]. So we&#8217;ve built a GP bench that&#8217;s really strong, and these GPs bring deals to our investment committee, and we make the decision as a committee.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How many bets per year are you making? And what size checks are you writing?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We typically invest between $50 million and $200 million in each company. We&#8217;re very thesis driven, so we spend a lot of time going deep on sectors . . and we&#8217;re investing in about seven or eight new companies a year and then typically [many] more follow-on [rounds] for our existing portfolio.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How much of a company do you aim to own?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We\u2019re flexible on ownership percentage. What we&#8217;re thinking about is our money-on-money returns in these companies. For example, I led the Series D round in Stripe back in 2017. I think that was a $9 billion valuation. [We closed] a recent AI investment that was on the earlier side \u2013 it had a sub $500 million valuation \u2013 so we&#8217;re very focused on the market, how much we think the business is differentiated, and whether we can invest a significant amount of capital to scale.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What are your cash-on-cash returns?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We don&#8217;t share those publicly. We don&#8217;t share any of the returns publicly.<\/p>\n<p><strong>At $9 billion, you&#8217;re going to do great with that investment in Stripe, whose valuation ran all the way up to $95 billion before it was reset at $50 billion last year. Do you think that valuation swing was in response to market trends or its performance?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Stripe is an incredible company and [tackling] absolutely one of the biggest market opportunities out there, so I&#8217;m very bullish on their performance to date and all that&#8217;s ahead. When you look at any valuations, public or private, across the last 18 to 24 months, all of them had some sort of reset based coming out of the COVID . . .so I wouldn&#8217;t read anything into the company\u2019s performance.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Does Alphabet allocate a discrete fund to you every year?\u00a0<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Yes, we invest out of discrete funds, so yearly annual funds.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How big are they?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We have $7 billion in assets under management [dating back to 2013].<\/p>\n<p><strong>So you have a lot of money in a market where others have less. With the IPO market stalled and other late-stage investors investing less, are you buying up secondary shares?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We&#8217;re very focused on partnerships with the CEO and the management team. We will only invest if we have engagement with the CEO and we have direct data from the company. Our model is we want to be the best partners to these founders so that they refer us to the next best companies down the line.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What secondary shares have you bought?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I won&#8217;t share specific companies because that hasn&#8217;t been [publicly disclosed by the companies]. And a lot of secondary sales end up structured as primary anyway. But the broader trend that you&#8217;re referring to is interesting because it is early-stage investors looking for liquidity. And I think that\u2019s right in line with our strategy of finding the best growth-stage companies and at what we believe is very early in their long-term compounding [trajectory], so we&#8217;re super excited to get on the cap table of those types of companies. . . Our strategy is to partner with these companies early and then hold them for a long period of time.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You do eventually distribute shares back to Alphabet, though.<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We definitely distribute, but I\u2019d say we have a long-term orientation.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Does Alphabet really care if you deliver returns? Are these bets mostly strategic?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We focus on delivering returns, and we focus on the mission of using the expertise and experience of Google and Alphabet to be world-class partners to these generational tech companies.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Google is obviously going big on AI. Tell me a bit about your own AI strategy.<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We\u2019re as excited about AI as everyone else. We have a really wonderful team of people focused on it within CapitalG, and that&#8217;s another area where we have some really great advisors within Google who have enabled us to lean into even more technical bets. Cybersecurity is a good example here. We were in CrowdStrike in the Series B when they had $15 million in revenue or something, and a big part of making some of those early cybersecurity bets was a differentiated technical point of view. So we&#8217;re bringing that same rigor to the AI space.<\/p>\n<p>One of the things that we think is really interesting in the AI space is, when we look across enterprise use cases, we actually think a lot of the incumbents are quite well-positioned, because they have distribution, they have customers, they have workflows . . .so where we&#8217;ve been looking a bit more is places where there&#8217;s real technical differentiation and where workflow and existing distribution is less important. One company that we\u2019ve backed that we believe has a strong, technical differentiation is <a href=\"https:\/\/capitalg.com\/insights\/magic-reimagining-software-engineering-with-ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Magic<\/a>, which is focused on building an AI software engineer.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You\u2019re also on the board of Duolingo, which parted ways with 10% of its contractors last month. A spokesperson said at the time that the company didn&#8217;t really need as many people, in part because of AI. Is that something that you&#8217;re seeing across your portfolio companies?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I won&#8217;t comment on Duolingo specifically, but I will say that across our portfolio companies, they are looking at how AI can enhance the customer experience, and enhance their other systems and processes. I think there&#8217;s a lot of surprise and delight around that. There&#8217;s a lot of rethinking of the marketing stack. There&#8217;s a lot of rethinking of customer support and services. We&#8217;re still in very early innings. But the same way I see enterprise customers excited to experiment with how they can use AI in their workflow, I see startup and growth-stage companies really excited to experiment with how they can use AI to rethink how they&#8217;re building the organization and get all of their employees focused on the most high-value opportunities. There&#8217;s a lot of interesting work happening there.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Almost a year ago, Alphabet\u2019s growth stage venture arm, CapitalG, named partner Laela Sturdy as its new head, just as the unit&#8217;s founder, David Lawee, stepped down. Few were surprised Sturdy was promoted to the post. She joined Google in 2007 in a marketing role, was pulled into a number of departments in the following [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":89646803,"featured_media":2666952,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"fbd65e67-8543-359b-8159-033187c2bb3a","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-17T06:12:46Z","apple_news_api_id":"9219d5a8-19da-4486-91e3-373c23ba6cb9","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-17T21:16:12Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAABg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AkhnVqBnaRIaR4zc8I7psuQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577030455],"tags":[],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- credit-score-based-dating-app-launches-and-an-anti-tesla-ad-comes-under-fire","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/openai-releases-sora-a-credit-score-based-dating-app-launches-and-an-anti-tesla-ad-comes-under-fire\/","title":{"rendered":"OpenAI releases Sora, a credit score\u2013based dating app launches and an anti-Tesla ad comes under fire"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Welcome, folks, to Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch&#8217;s regular newsletter covering noteworthy happenings in the tech industry.<\/p>\n<p>This week, OpenAI stunned the blogosphere with the release of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/openais-newest-model-can-generate-videos-and-they-look-decent\/\">Sora<\/a>, a new AI model that can generate videos in impressively high fidelity. We&#8217;ve seen video generators before. But what makes Sora unique is its understanding of time and physics, which enable it to create not only more coherent videos than previous video generators, but also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/openais-sora-video-generating-model-can-render-video-games-too\/\">3D worlds<\/a>. Wild stuff!<\/p>\n<p>Elsewhere, startup <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/score-is-a-new-dating-app-for-people-with-good-to-excellent-credit\/?mrfhud=true\">Score<\/a> released a dating app exclusive to people with good to excellent credit scores. And an anti-Tesla Super Bowl ad <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/dawn-project-tesla-ad-fsd-ntsb\/?mrfhud=true\">came under fire<\/a> from the National Transportation Safety Board for using its seal without authorization.<\/p>\n<p>Lots else happened. We recap it all in this edition of WiR &#8212; but first, a reminder to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\">sign up<\/a>\u00a0to receive the WiR newsletter in your inbox every Saturday.<\/p>\n<h2>News<\/h2>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/airbnb-is-making-progress-to-get-rid-of-those-hated-cleaning-fees\/?mrfhud=true\">Cleaning fees begone:<\/a> <\/strong>Airbnb is slowly killing the cleaning fee as it aims for more transparent pricing, Amanda writes.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/every-noise-shut-down-spotify-layoffs\/?mrfhud=true\">Silenced before its time:<\/a><\/strong> Layoffs at Spotify have put an end to Glenn McDonald&#8217;s beloved Every Noise at Once project, a musical encyclopedia of sorts &#8212; and fans are pissed.<\/p>\n<p><b><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/mozilla-downsizes-as-it-refocuses-on-firefox-and-ai-read-the-memo\/?mrfhud=true\">Mozilla downsizes:<\/a> <\/b>Following downsizing, Mozilla plans to scale back its investment in a number of products, including its VPN, Relay and Online Footprint Scrubber, Frederic reports.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/google-makes-more-gemini-models-available-to-developers-but-needs-to-work-on-its-branding\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Google upgrades Gemini: <\/strong><\/a>Google expanded the range of its Gemini AI models available to developers across its platforms. And it&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/googles-new-gemini-model-can-analyze-an-hour-long-video-but-few-people-can-use-it\/?mrfhud=true\">previewed<\/a> a new Gemini model capable of analyzing whole books, hours-long audio and hour-long videos.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/slack-brings-ai-fueled-search-and-summarization-to-the-platform\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Slack gets GenAI:<\/strong><\/a> Slack introduced a couple of new features designed to make information more accessible, including a new AI-fueled search tool and the ability to summarize information inside channels.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/variston-spyware-losing-staff-some-say-closing\/\">Variston folds:<\/a><\/strong> Spyware startup Variston is losing staff &#8212; and some say it&#8217;s closing up shop entirely. The Barcelona-based startup&#8217;s malware has been used to target iPhones, Android devices and PCs, Lorenzo writes.<\/p>\n<h2>Analysis<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/bluesky-and-mastodon-users-are-having-a-fight-that-could-shape-the-next-generation-of-social-media\/?mrfhud=true\"><b>Bluesky vs. Mastodon:<\/b><\/a> Amanda writes about the fight over how &#8212; and whether &#8212; to bridge the two decentralized social networks Bluesky and Mastodon and how it could shape the future of the internet.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/09\/epic-games-disney-fortnite-metaverse\/?mrfhud=true\">Fortnite and the Mouse:<\/a> <\/strong>With Disney\u2019s magic (&#8220;magic&#8221; here referring to IP and a $1.5 billion investment), Fortnite is poised to win the metaverse, Taylor writes.<\/p>\n<h2>Podcasts<\/h2>\n<p>On <strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/equity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Equity<\/a><\/strong>, the crew talked about how Bret Taylor\u2019s new startup, Sierra, is turning heads. Taylor &#8212; known for his work at Facebook, Salesforce and OpenAI &#8212; says that Sierra is about building conversational AI agents.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/found\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Found<\/a><\/strong> profiled Tigran Sloyan, co-founder and CEO of CodeSignal, a skills assessment platform used by many tech companies to hire engineers based on their engineering chops rather than their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s.<\/p>\n<p>And <strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/chainreaction\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction<\/a><\/strong> had on Yat Siu, executive chairman of Animoca Brands, which has invested in over 400 web3 projects across a range of sectors like DeFi, education, infrastructure, blockchain gaming and the metaverse.<\/p>\n<h2>TechCrunch+<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/10\/vcs-are-no-longer-gunshy-about-firearm-startups\/\"><strong>Flash in the pan:<\/strong><\/a> Rebecca writes how, for a variety of reasons, VCs are no longer gun-shy about firearm startups.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/these-founders-want-a-more-ethical-company-structure-for-startups\/\"><strong>Demand for ethics:<\/strong><\/a>\u00a0Regenerative community organism (RCO), a novel organizational model that aims to be a practical approach to integrating sustainability at the core of operations, is gaining steam in the startup world, Haje reports.<\/p>\n<h2>Bonus round<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/foundry-group-is-shutting-down-and-wont-raise-another-fund\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Foundry Group shutters:<\/strong><\/a> Foundry Group, an 18-year-old venture firm with nearly $3.5 billion in assets under management, has quietly decided to shut down and not raise any more funds.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/apple-confirms-its-breaking-iphone-web-apps-in-the-eu-on-purpose\/?mrfhud=true\">Playing hardball:<\/a><\/strong> Apple has confirmed that it\u2019s breaking iPhone web apps in the European Union (EU) on purpose &#8212; blaming the new EU regulation, the Digital Markets Act, for the change.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Welcome, folks, to Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch&#8217;s regular newsletter covering noteworthy happenings in the tech industry. This week, OpenAI stunned the blogosphere with the release of Sora, a new AI model that can generate videos in impressively high fidelity. We&#8217;ve seen video generators before. But what makes Sora unique is its understanding of time Link","children":[]},{"id":2593262,"order":6,"parent":0,"text":"Mastodon","url":"https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":2593262,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2666680,"date":"2024-02-18T10:00:45","date_gmt":"2024-02-18T18:00:45","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666680"},"modified":"2024-02-16T10:53:43","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T18:53:43","slug":"miruku-plant-dairy-food-tech","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/18\/miruku-plant-dairy-food-tech\/","title":{"rendered":"Miruku grabs more capital as its plant-based dairy tech reaches proof of concept"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">While the food tech investment sector figured itself out last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.miruku.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Miruku<\/a>, a New Zealand-based food tech company, was busy getting ahead of molecular farming technology. That proactive strategy put the company about \u201cthree to four years ahead of emerging competitors,\u201d CEO Amos Palfreyman told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cMiruku has not only aimed to navigate the challenges presented by the shifting climate impacting traditional dairy production, but has also broadened our focus to address critical issues of food security and nutrition,\u201d Palfreyman said via an email interview.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/21\/miruku-replacing-animals-with-plants-to-create-dairy-proteins\/\">TechCrunch profiled the company in 2022<\/a> when it raised $2.4 million in seed funding to develop molecular farming technology to program plant cells to be mini factories for producing proteins and other molecules, like fats and sugars, traditionally made by animals.<\/p>\n<p>Miruku is not alone in using molecular farming technologies to create <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/the-future-of-milk-is-milk\/\">dairy products<\/a>. Mozza Foods and Nobell Foods do as well, but Palfreyman says his company focuses on business-to-business and modifies both proteins and fats within the same plant. It also chose to use safflower as its primary crop due to its climate resilience.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"pOWDqZ8aby\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/21\/miruku-replacing-animals-with-plants-to-create-dairy-proteins\/\">Miruku replacing animals with plants to create dairy proteins<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Miruku replacing animals with plants to create dairy proteins&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/21\/miruku-replacing-animals-with-plants-to-create-dairy-proteins\/embed\/#?secret=CuWpNPm2Mu#?secret=pOWDqZ8aby\" data-secret=\"pOWDqZ8aby\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2666686\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2666686\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2666686\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg\" alt=\"Miruku\u2019s management, from top left, Ira Bing, Thomas Buchanan, Amos Palfreyman,and Abby Thompson. (Image credit: Miruku)\" width=\"1024\" height=\"576\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg 1872w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/Miruku-NZ-management-1.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2666686\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Miruku\u2019s management, from left, Thomas Buchanan, Ira Bing, Amos Palfreyman and Abby Thompson. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Miruku<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Since the seed round, the company made advancements in its proprietary dairy seed system. Initially, Miruku focused on programming plants to produce dairy proteins that could be extracted from seeds. That approach has since expanded to leverage interactions between recombinant dairy casein and native plant proteins, with or without improved fatty acid profiles.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>\u201cThis breakthrough allows us to utilize a larger portion of the seed, transforming it into a range of versatile ingredients tailored for the food and beverage industry,\u201d Palfreyman said. \u201cWe\u2019ve now reached several key proof-of-concept milestones demonstrating the viability and potential of the dairy seed system.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>During that time, the company also tripled the size of its team and formed relationships with a number of food manufacturing partners for some co-development opportunities. In addition, Miruku broadened its footprint to Israel as well as Australia, which was selected as the launchpad for initial market entry.<\/p>\n<p>Today, the company announced $5 million in what Palfreyman called a pre-Series A round. It was led by Motion Capital and included seed round investor Movac and new investor NZVC. He didn\u2019t disclose the valuation, but did say it was an \u201cup round.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>The new capital enables Miruku to expand its crop development efforts. This includes a partnership with CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization), the Australian government agency responsible for scientific research. As such, the company will take its modified safflower varieties into field trials in Australia, Palfreyman said.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cAbove all, our priority is to advance our technology and progress towards market readiness,\u201d Palfreyman said. \u201cThis includes expanding our footprint in Australia and looking at establishing a presence in the United States.\u201d<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"lsdyLB9n81\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/the-future-of-milk-is-milk\/\">The future of milk is \u2026 milk?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;The future of milk is \u2026 milk?&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" profiles.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574474,"featured_media":2666685,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"30491b87-9bf0-3265-912e-8937c02c5506","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-18T18:00:59Z","apple_news_api_id":"816af2df-127d-4c6d-acc1-695051a4e089","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-18T18:00:59Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAD\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/w==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AgWry3xJ9TG2swWlQUaTgiQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[20429,577030455],"tags":[577232074,4483661,447984981,576996543,577232077,577058174],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- dairy | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"description":"Read the latest news about plant-based dairy on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577058174"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577058174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577058174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577058174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577058174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577058174"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666217,"date":"2024-02-18T10:00:26","date_gmt":"2024-02-18T18:00:26","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666217"},"modified":"2024-02-16T10:17:23","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T18:17:23","slug":"twilio-activist-pressure-segment-sale","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/18\/twilio-activist-pressure-segment-sale\/","title":{"rendered":"With Twilio under activist pressure, Segment could be put up for sale"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Twilio\u2019s foray into<\/span> the customer data (CDP) business could be heading for an early conclusion. The former startup offers communications software services via APIs, and in recent years expanded its product footprint through the acquisition of companies like Segment, which added CDP capabilities to its larger portfolio.<\/p>\n<p>Now, in the wake of the company\u2019s growth <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/05\/twilio-layoffs-activist-investors\/\">slowing to a near halt in late 2023<\/a> and the exit of its <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/08\/jeff-lawsons-legacy-at-twilio-is-about-more-than-a-few-rough-quarters\/#:~:text=Khozema%20Shipchandler%2C%20Twilio's%20president%20and,The%20Exchange%20newsletter%20every%20Saturday.\">founding CEO<\/a> Jeff Lawson, Twilio is executing \u201can extensive operational review\u201d of the asset, according to its recent earnings call. Asked by an analyst if the review could result in a sale, the company stressed that Segment has strategic value, but that it is approaching its review of the business \u201cwith an open mind.\u201d That doesn\u2019t necessarily bode well for Segment to remain part of the company much longer.<\/p>\n<p>During the last quarters of Lawson\u2019s tenure atop the company, Twilio came under pressure from activist investors Anson Funds and Legion Capital to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/11\/28\/activist-fund-anson-takes-twilio-stake-urges-board-to-sell.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">divest assets<\/a> to bolster shareholder value. Twilio\u2019s own share price soared to more than $400 per share in 2021 before falling to $72.27 Wednesday before the company shared its fourth-quarter performance. The stock price was off another 15% on Thursday to $61.15 per share, suggesting that investors weren&#8217;t thrilled with the report.<\/p>\n<p>Whether Twilio will actually sell Segment is an open question right now, but if it does, activists are betting that it will increase the value of the parent company by focusing on its core communications business.<\/p>\n<h2>Twilio\u2019s history with Segment<\/h2>\n<p>When activist investors start circling a company, one CEO who went through the experience said that the first thing to do is to figure out if maybe they\u2019re right, or at least partly right, in their assessment. That takes an ability to step back and see what they\u2019re complaining about.<\/p>\n<p>In this case, it\u2019s about a big acquisition and whether it was the best place to put resources. Ah, but hindsight is always 20\/20, isn\u2019t it, especially in this case. Think back to October 2020 when we were at the height of the pandemic, and Twilio was flush with a healthy market cap of over $40 billion. With all that value and an eye toward expanding its market, Twilio went out and spent $3.2 billion <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/12\/twilio-confirms-it-is-buying-segment-for-3-2b-in-an-all-stock-deal\/\">to acquire Segment<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Segment was a high-flying startup that raised over $283 million. Its last round in 2019, a year before the acquisition, was a $175 million Series D at a $1.5 billion post-money valuation, per PitchBook. It was also a time where companies were really beginning to understand the value of customer data by bringing it into a single view, and Segment was one of the top startups going after large incumbents like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/03\/26\/adobe-and-salesforce-announce-customer-data-platforms-to-pull-data-into-single-view\/\">Salesforce and Adobe<\/a>.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>But it was fair to ask, even at the time, where Segment would fit inside a company where the core business was building communications APIs. The consensus was that Twilio wanted to help customers build <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/12\/twilios-3-2b-segment-acquisition-about-helping-developers-build-data-fueled-apps\/\">data-fueled<\/a> customer-centric applications to take advantage of the data stored in the Segment CDP to provide a new growth path for the company.<\/p>\n<p>It felt like that growth path was in reach, a way to expand the company\u2019s markets beyond the communications APIs business. It actually made sense until the market shifted pretty dramatically post-pandemic and Twilio\u2019s stock price plunged.<\/p>\n<p>With its market cap dropping, Twilio was left with an asset that wasn\u2019t really pulling its weight, making it vulnerable to activist investor complaints about where it fits in the business. The question is whether activists are putting the company in an impossible position.<\/p>\n<h2>What is Segment worth?<\/h2>\n<p>In its most recent earnings report, Twilio moved its \u201cFlex and Marketing Campaigns products\u201d to its Communications line of business, leaving its former Data and Applications unit much slimmed and now operating under the Segment name. It also includes some non-Segment efforts, like the company\u2019s Engage products.<\/p>\n<p>According <a href=\"https:\/\/s21.q4cdn.com\/963721274\/files\/doc_financials\/2023\/q4\/Q4-23-Earnings-Presentation_FINAL.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">to Twilio<\/a>, its Segment unit generated $75 million worth of revenue in Q4 2023, up 4% from a $73 million result in the year-ago quarter. Its gross margin slipped 80 basis points to 74.4%, posted a non-GAAP operating margin of \u201324.6% and saw its dollar-based net expansion rate improve by 2% to 96% compared to its Q4 2022 metrics.<\/p>\n<p>In simpler terms, Segment is not growing much, is seeing its revenue quality decline slightly, and is still seeing spend from existing customers contract. (Twilio took a charge relating to Segment in its most recent quarter: $286 million regarding \u201cdeveloped technology and customer relationship intangible assets,\u201d which it added did not include any of Segment\u2019s \u201creporting unit goodwill.\u201d)<\/p>\n<p>Given Segment&#8217;s known underperformance \u2014 in its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fool.com\/earnings\/call-transcripts\/2024\/02\/14\/twilio-twlo-q4-2023-earnings-call-transcript\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">earnings call<\/a>, Twilio\u2019s new CEO Khozema Shipchandler said that Segment is \u201cnot performing at the level it needs to,\u201d adding later that its main priority is \u201cmitigating churn and contraction\u201d \u2014 and a more conservative market for tech valuations at present compared to late 2020, it\u2019s doubtful that Twilio could hope to get <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/02\/twilio-wraps-3-2b-purchase-of-segment-after-warp-speed-courtship\/\">the $3.2 billion it spent on the company<\/a> back in a sale. This perspective has been <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cbinsights.com\/research\/twilio-segment-activist-investors\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">floating around<\/a> since even before the company better-surfaced Segment\u2019s metrics. Now with more data, we can be more precise.<\/p>\n<p>Segment\u2019s business unit at Twilio generated $295 million worth of revenue in 2023, up 7% year-over-year. If we anticipate that Segment will manage the same growth this year, the business unit would close 2024 with about $316 million in revenue.<\/p>\n<p>With that growth rate in hand, Segment would likely be valued similarly to other, slowly growing software businesses. Market data analyzed by <a href=\"https:\/\/cloudedjudgement.substack.com\/p\/clouded-judgement-2924-dilution-dilution\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Altimeter\u2019s Jamin Ball indicates<\/a> that software companies that are growing at 15% or less per year are worth about 4.4x their next 12 months\u2019 revenue. At that multiple, Segment is worth about $1.4 billion.<\/p>\n<p>You could argue that even that figure is a bit rich, given that Segment has stiffly negative operating margins, even on an adjusted basis. Some companies in its growth bucket have better profitability ratios, so we might expect Segment to earn a multiple in a sale that was slightly lower than the median figure that Ball calculated.<\/p>\n<p>At the same time, the value of Segment won\u2019t necessarily be measured directly from its potential public-market worth. If a buyer can be found that has a particular need or use for what Segment offers, Twilio might be able to juice a light premium. But no matter whether you adjust up or down, Segment\u2019s growth rate and revenue base give it a light-unicorn value by current metrics, and nothing close to what it sold for.<\/p>\n<p>It was easier to value software businesses at higher levels when growth was faster and money cheaper. Indeed, when the deal <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/13\/is-the-twilio-segment-deal-expensive\/\">was covered by TechCrunch<\/a>, we noted that by then-current norms it didn\u2019t seem too expensive. Segment was also growing at more than 50% at the time, a figure that has dramatically come down in the intervening years. No matter, it\u2019s hard to buy a company when software revenue multiples are in the high teens, see it decelerate, and then try to get your money back when single-digit multiples are the norm.<\/p>\n<p>Apart from valuation dickering, another $1.4 billion in cash might not really change the game for Twilio. The company is worth around $11 billion today, has more than $4 billion in cash and equivalents, and under $1 billion worth of debt. So with more cash, it could extinguish debt and bolster its share buyback program, but the money doesn\u2019t seem transformative for the parent org, given that it is cash-rich and debt-light.<\/p>\n<p>This is the conundrum: Investors want action and news that could bolster Twilio\u2019s share price. They have lobbied for Segment to be sold off to help improve the value of their holdings. But Segment is only so valuable today, and the company is stuck deciding between potential strategic gains from keeping one foot in the realm of CDP and divesting an asset at a loss that would see its revenue base erode. That\u2019s a tough spot to be in.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>With Twilio under pressure from activist investors, it&#8217;s looking at whether to sell Segment, the company it bought in 2020 for $3.2 billion.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":521068,"featured_media":2666223,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"a911ac39-c9e7-3f38-9599-f933155908ab","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-18T18:00:44Z","apple_news_api_id":"fee0912a-f179-4e92-927c-4f4e9f29401f","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-18T18:00:44Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAD\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/w==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A_uCRKvF5TpKSfE9OnylAHw","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[449557044],"tags":[576645869,448437081,13794425],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!--
