echcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/18\/women-in-ai-eva-maydell-member-of-european-parliament-and-eu-ai-act-advisor\/","title":{"rendered":"Women In AI: Eva Maydell, member of European Parliament and EU AI Act advisor"},"content":{"rendered":"<p dir=\"ltr\" role=\"presentation\">To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">series of interviews<\/a> focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more profiles <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\" role=\"presentation\">Eva Maydell is a Bulgarian politician and a member of European Parliament. First elected to Parliament in 2014 at age 28, she was the youngest member serving at the time. In 2019, Maydell was re-elected to Parliament, where she continues to serve on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE).<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\" role=\"presentation\">Maydell was the ITRE rapporteur for the EU AI Act, the proposed legal framework to govern the sale and use of AI in the European Union, and as such was in charge of drafting a report on the proposal of the European Commission &#8212; reflecting the opinion of ITRE members. Maydell &#8212; in consultation with outside experts and stakeholders &#8212; was also responsible for drafting compromise amendments.<\/p>\n<h2 dir=\"ltr\" role=\"presentation\">Eva Maydell, member of European Parliament<\/h2>\n<h3>Briefly, how did you get your start in AI? What attracted you to the field?<\/h3>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">When I first became a member of the European Parliament, I was one of the few young female members of European Parliament (MEPs) that worked on tech issues. I\u2019ve always been passionate about how Europe can better leverage the huge opportunities of tech innovation. The great thing about working on tech is that you\u2019re always looking to the future. Having worked on cybersecurity, semiconductors and the digital agenda throughout my time in the Parliament, I knew I would find working on the AI Act incredibly interesting and be able to utilise my experience in those areas on this world first piece of regulation.<\/p>\n<h3>What work are you most proud of (in the AI field)?<\/h3>\n<p>I\u2019m proud of the work we\u2019ve done on the AI Act. We have laid out a common European vision for the future of this technology &#8212; one in which AI is more democratic, safe and innovative. Regulators and Parliaments naturally think about how to protect and prepare for worst-case scenarios and the risks; but I also pushed hard for competitiveness to be at the heart of this conversation. This included championing a research and open source exemption, an ambitious approach to regulatory sandboxes and aligning our work with our international partners as much as possible to reduce market frictions.<\/p>\n<h3>How do you navigate the challenges of the male-dominated tech industry, and, by extension, the male-dominated AI industry?<\/h3>\n<p>We\u2019re slowly but surely seeing more women in tech and AI. I have female colleagues and friends that work in tech who are incredibly talented and really driving the tech agenda. It\u2019s great that we have that network to support each other. I have also found that I have been embraced by the AI community and it\u2019s what makes working on this issue so interesting and enjoyable.<\/p>\n<h3>What advice would you give to women seeking to enter the AI field?<\/h3>\n<p>Just go for it! Be yourself, don\u2019t think you have to stick to the mould or be like other people. Everyone has something unique to offer. The more women keep sharing their ideas, visions and voice, the more they will inspire other women to step into the world of tech. Whenever I speak with student groups, or young MEPs, it\u2019s wonderful to see so many women interested in entering this field &#8212; you can feel the change taking place.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<h3>What are some of the most pressing issues facing AI as it evolves?<\/h3>\n<p>The greatest challenge for any politician working on tech and AI is trying to regulate and prepare for the future with accuracy. Despite all the facts, figures and research, there&#8217;s a certain element of looking into a &#8220;crystal ball.&#8221; The big issues politicians will need to address are:<\/p>\n<p>Firstly, how can this technology make our economies more competitive while ensuring wider social benefit? Secondly, how do we stop AI fuelling disinformation? And thirdly, how do we set international rules to ensure AI is developed and utilized according to democratic standards?<\/p>\n<h3>What are some issues AI users should be aware of?<\/h3>\n<p>The very serious challenge posed by AI as a vehicle to accelerate the spread of disinformation and deepfakes. This is particularly important this year, given 50% of the world will go to the polls to vote. We all need to use a critical eye on the images, videos and news articles we see. As the technology improves, we need to become more vigilant to being manipulated. This is an issue I\u2019m working on extensively right now.<\/p>\n<h3>What is the best way to responsibly build AI?<\/h3>\n<p>If we want a future in which AI improves our lives and helps solve our most pressing challenges, then there&#8217;s one key ingredient: trust. We need trust in these technologies.<\/p>\n<p>We can\u2019t afford to rest on our laurels. The AI Act doesn&#8217;t mean we&#8217;re &#8220;one and done.&#8221; We need to keep asking ourselves what\u2019s next &#8212; and that doesn\u2019t necessarily mean more regulation. But it does mean keeping a constant eye on the big picture &#8212; how AI and the regulation is affecting our economy, security and lives.<\/p>\n<h3>How can investors better push for responsible AI?<\/h3>\n<p>Investing in AI or any innovative technology is no different to investing in any other product. Business, banks and corporations are aware of the fact that there are significant financial merits on being a positive force in the world around us. Ultimately, scaling AI in a responsible way is more likely to sustain success, reduce financial risks and failures, and therefore, create consumer and market confidence.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a series of interviews focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more ink":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/18\/paypal-ventures-first-ai-investment-a-credit-based-dating-app-and-robinhoods-good-week\/","title":{"rendered":"PayPal Ventures&#8217; first AI investment, a credit-based dating app and Robinhood&#8217;s good week"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Welcome to TechCrunch Fintech (formerly The Interchange)! This week, we\u2019re looking at a new finance-based dating app, Robinhood&#8217;s earnings results and the startup in which PayPal Ventures made its first investment. Let\u2019s dive in!<\/em><\/p>\n<p><em>To get a roundup of TechCrunch\u2019s biggest and most important fintech stories delivered to your inbox every Sunday at 7:30 a.m. PT,\u00a0<\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">subscribe here<\/a><em>.<\/em><\/p>\n<h2>The big story<\/h2>\n<p>A new dating app was released just in time for Valentine\u2019s Day, but there\u2019s a catch: You must have at least a 675 credit score to use it. Launched by financial platform Neon Money Club, Score is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/score-is-a-new-dating-app-for-people-with-good-to-excellent-credit\/\">a dating app for people with good to excellent credit<\/a>, and it seeks to help raise awareness about the importance of finances in relationships. TC\u2019s Dominic-Madori Davis gave us a look at what the startup aims to do and how it came about. Reading all the comments on X and LI was also quite entertaining!<\/p>\n<h2>Analysis of the week<\/h2>\n<p>Robinhood\u2019s stock got a big boost last week when the company posted a surprise profit in the fourth quarter \u201cdriven by higher interest income from customers paying back loans and a rebound in trading,&#8221; according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/business\/finance\/robinhoods-q4-revenue-rises-interest-income-boost-2024-02-13\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Reuters<\/a>. It also revealed that it could be breakeven or profitable <a href=\"https:\/\/finance.yahoo.com\/news\/robinhood-markets-inc-nasdaq-hood-100428740.html?fr=yhssrp_catchall\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">by next year<\/a>. Shares climbed to their highest price last week in nearly two years and closed at $14 on Friday, up 17% from a close of $11.94 on February 13. When public fintechs do well, it usually means good things for privately held fintechs. CEO and co-founder Vlad Tenev spoke at TechCrunch Disrupt last year \u2014 read all about that <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/19\/robinhood-ceo-on-the-companys-evolution-weve-made-a-lot-of-progress\/\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h2>Dollars and cents<\/h2>\n<p>Finom, a European challenger bank aimed at SMEs and freelancers, has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/finom-a-european-challenger-bank-for-smes-raises-54m\/\">raised \u20ac50 million <\/a>($54 million) in a Series B equity round of funding.<\/p>\n<p>FlowFi, a startup creating a marketplace of finance experts for entrepreneurs, closed on <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/flowfi-accounting-fintech-startups\/\">$9 million in seed funding<\/a>. Blumberg Capital led the investment.<\/p>\n<p>Bold, a financial technology company building an electronic payments infrastructure in Colombia, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/general-atlantic-50m-bold-digital-payments-colombia\/\">raised $50 million in Series C funding<\/a> in a round led by existing investor General Atlantic.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Rasa, an enterprise-focused conversational generative AI platform with financial services companies as clients, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/rasa-an-enterprise-focused-dev-platform-for-conversational-genai-raises-30m\/\">raised $30 million<\/a> in a Series C round co-led by StepStone Capital and PayPal Ventures. Notably, this marked PayPal\u2019s first AI investment.<\/p>\n<h2>What else we\u2019re writing<\/h2>\n<p>India is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/india-stumped-on-how-to-cut-phonepe-google-dominance-in-upi-payments\/\">facing a quandary<\/a> in enforcing long-delayed rules to curb the dominance of PhonePe and Google Pay in the country\u2019s ubiquitous UPI payments network, which processes over 10 billion transactions monthly.<\/p>\n<p>After recent launches in the U.K. and Ireland, workforce management platform Rippling is continuing its ambitious international expansion with the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/rippling-2\/\">opening of its Asia-Pacific headquarters<\/a> in Sydney, Australia. The company also <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/rippling-hr-startup-growth-parker-conrad-eisar-lipkovitz\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">poached<\/a> Eisar Lipkovitz from JPMorgan to serve as its new chief product officer.<\/p>\n<p>Apple\u2019s recent move to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/30\/apple-card-users-earned-more-than-1-billion-in-daily-cash-in-2023\/\">boost the interest rate<\/a> for its Apple Card savings account to 4.5% is now prompting a competitor to do the same. Cash App announced it will now offer \u201cup to\u201d a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/cash-app-takes-on-apple-with-a-4-5-apy-for-savings-accounts-with-direct-deposit\/\">4.5% APY (annual percentage yield) for its Cash App Savings customers<\/a>, with a few caveats.<\/p>\n<h2>Other high-interest headlines<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/bolt-once-worth-11-billion-slashes-price-97-in-buyback\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bolt, once worth $11B, slashes share price 97% in buyback\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/thefinancialbrand.com\/news\/fintech-banking\/venture-capitals-optimistic-that-fintech-deals-will-rebound-in-2024-174835\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Venture capital\u2019s optimistic that fintech deals will rebound in 2024<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/financialit.net\/news\/fundraising-news\/parlay-raises-13m-offer-inclusive-access-financial-resources-small-businesses\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Parlay raises $1.3M to offer inclusive access to financial resources for small businesses<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.pymnts.com\/news\/investment-tracker\/2024\/mia-share-raises-6-5-million-to-facilitate-digital-tuition-payments\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mia Share raises $6.5 million to facilitate digital tuition payments<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/sequoia-pressures-former-leader-moritz-to-leave-klarna-board-seat\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sequoia pressures former leader Moritz to leave Klarna board seat<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a Schulz to procurement role<\/a><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/tech.eu\/2024\/02\/12\/fintech-garners-over-one-third-of-last-week-s-745m-invested-in-european-tech\/\" target=\"_blank\" 2024\/02\/17\/dutch-startup-monumental-is-using-robots-to-lay-bricks\/","title":{"rendered":"Dutch startup Monumental is using robots to lay bricks"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Few categories are as ripe for automation-fueled disruption as construction. The industry is valued at around $2 trillion a year, in the U.S. alone. Much of that work is strenuous, repetitive and sometimes dangerous &#8212; precisely the sorts of problems industrial robotics are built to solve. The other thing construction brings is a wide range of different challenges, meaning that more startups can operate in the space without being in direct competition.<\/p>\n<p>Bricklaying robots aren\u2019t exactly an untapped concept. At the moment, Hadrian X is probably the best known player in the space. The U.S. firm specializes in building structures out of large concrete masonry blocks. Amsterdam-based <a href=\"https:\/\/www.monumental.co\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Monumental<\/a>, meanwhile, specializes in the more familiar red clay variety.<\/p>\n<p>The startup was founded in 2021 by the pair behind data visualization firm Silk (now a Palantir joint). Monumental has already been doing limited pilots in its native Netherlands, including the 15-meter exterior of an office building. Partnerships with 25 contractors have followed, including low-income housing.<\/p>\n<p>I can\u2019t speak much to the efficacy of the system beyond what I\u2019ve seen in some video demos, but can say that the company appears to be tackling the problem from a variety of fronts, beginning with an autonomous cart designed to shoulder heavy payloads. From there, another robot spreads liquid mortar and places bricks.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cAt Monumental, we\u2019re working to help the industry meet these challenges,\u201d says co-founder and CEO Salar al Khafaji. \u201cOur agile, intelligent, and adaptable robots and software blend human expertise with robotic efficiency in a way that the industry has never seen before.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>To celebrate its coming-out party, Monumental is also announcing a sizable $25 million round,\u00a0 led by Plural and Hummingbird, with participation from Northzone, Foundamental and NP-Hard Ventures.<\/p>\n<p>Funding will go toward hiring, scaling manufacturing and diversifying the manner of bricks\/blocks its robots are capable of handling.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Few categories are as ripe for automation-fueled disruption as construction. The industry is valued at around $2 trillion a year, in the U.S. alone. Much of that work is strenuous, repetitive and sometimes dangerous &#8212; precisely the sorts of problems industrial robotics are built to solve. The other thing construction brings is a wide range [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":699688,"featured_media":2666876,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"bbd5b5ed-a04d-3e7b-845f-ff199eabaf5e","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"","apple_news_api_id":"","apple_news_api_modified_at":"","apple_news_api_revision":"","apple_news_api_share_url":"","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[449223024,577123751,20429],"tags":[19994,61936114,577232120],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>Dutch startup Monumental is using robots to lay bricks | TechCrunch<\/title>\n<meta name=\"description\" content=\"Few categories are as ripe for automation-fueled disruption as construction. releases Sora, a credit score\u2013based dating app launches and an anti-Tesla ad comes under fire"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Welcome, folks, to Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch&#8217;s regular newsletter covering noteworthy happenings in the tech industry.<\/p>\n<p>This week, OpenAI stunned the blogosphere with the release of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/openais-newest-model-can-generate-videos-and-they-look-decent\/\">Sora<\/a>, a new AI model that can generate videos in impressively high fidelity. We&#8217;ve seen video generators before. But what makes Sora unique is its understanding of time and physics, which enable it to create not only more coherent videos than previous video generators, but also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/openais-sora-video-generating-model-can-render-video-games-too\/\">3D worlds<\/a>. Wild stuff!<\/p>\n<p>Elsewhere, startup <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/score-is-a-new-dating-app-for-people-with-good-to-excellent-credit\/?mrfhud=true\">Score<\/a> released a dating app exclusive to people with good to excellent credit scores. And an anti-Tesla Super Bowl ad <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/dawn-project-tesla-ad-fsd-ntsb\/?mrfhud=true\">came under fire<\/a> from the National Transportation Safety Board for using its seal without authorization.<\/p>\n<p>Lots else happened. We recap it all in this edition of WiR &#8212; but first, a reminder to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\">sign up<\/a>\u00a0to receive the WiR newsletter in your inbox every Saturday.<\/p>\n<h2>News<\/h2>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/airbnb-is-making-progress-to-get-rid-of-those-hated-cleaning-fees\/?mrfhud=true\">Cleaning fees begone:<\/a> <\/strong>Airbnb is slowly killing the cleaning fee as it aims for more transparent pricing, Amanda writes.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/every-noise-shut-down-spotify-layoffs\/?mrfhud=true\">Silenced before its time:<\/a><\/strong> Layoffs at Spotify have put an end to Glenn McDonald&#8217;s beloved Every Noise at Once project, a musical encyclopedia of sorts &#8212; and fans are pissed.<\/p>\n<p><b><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/mozilla-downsizes-as-it-refocuses-on-firefox-and-ai-read-the-memo\/?mrfhud=true\">Mozilla downsizes:<\/a> <\/b>Following downsizing, Mozilla plans to scale back its investment in a number of products, including its VPN, Relay and Online Footprint Scrubber, Frederic reports.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/google-makes-more-gemini-models-available-to-developers-but-needs-to-work-on-its-branding\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Google upgrades Gemini: <\/strong><\/a>Google expanded the range of its Gemini AI models available to developers across its platforms. And it&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/googles-new-gemini-model-can-analyze-an-hour-long-video-but-few-people-can-use-it\/?mrfhud=true\">previewed<\/a> a new Gemini model capable of analyzing whole books, hours-long audio and hour-long videos.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/slack-brings-ai-fueled-search-and-summarization-to-the-platform\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Slack gets GenAI:<\/strong><\/a> Slack introduced a couple of new features designed to make information more accessible, including a new AI-fueled search tool and the ability to summarize information inside channels.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/variston-spyware-losing-staff-some-say-closing\/\">Variston folds:<\/a><\/strong> Spyware startup Variston is losing staff &#8212; and some say it&#8217;s closing up shop entirely. The Barcelona-based startup&#8217;s malware has been used to target iPhones, Android devices and PCs, Lorenzo writes.<\/p>\n<h2>Analysis<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/bluesky-and-mastodon-users-are-having-a-fight-that-could-shape-the-next-generation-of-social-media\/?mrfhud=true\"><b>Bluesky vs. Mastodon:<\/b><\/a> Amanda writes about the fight over how &#8212; and whether &#8212; to bridge the two decentralized social networks Bluesky and Mastodon and how it could shape the future of the internet.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/09\/epic-games-disney-fortnite-metaverse\/?mrfhud=true\">Fortnite and the Mouse:<\/a> <\/strong>With Disney\u2019s magic (&#8220;magic&#8221; here referring to IP and a $1.5 billion investment), Fortnite is poised to win the metaverse, Taylor writes.<\/p>\n<h2>Podcasts<\/h2>\n<p>On <strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/equity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Equity<\/a><\/strong>, the crew talked about how Bret Taylor\u2019s new startup, Sierra, is turning heads. Taylor &#8212; known for his work at Facebook, Salesforce and OpenAI &#8212; says that Sierra is about building conversational AI agents.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/found\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Found<\/a><\/strong> profiled Tigran Sloyan, co-founder and CEO of CodeSignal, a skills assessment platform used by many tech companies to hire engineers based on their engineering chops rather than their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s.<\/p>\n<p>And <strong><a href=\"https:\/\/pod.link\/chainreaction\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction<\/a><\/strong> had on Yat Siu, executive chairman of Animoca Brands, which has invested in over 400 web3 projects across a range of sectors like DeFi, education, infrastructure, blockchain gaming and the metaverse.<\/p>\n<h2>TechCrunch+<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/10\/vcs-are-no-longer-gunshy-about-firearm-startups\/\"><strong>Flash in the pan:<\/strong><\/a> Rebecca writes how, for a variety of reasons, VCs are no longer gun-shy about firearm startups.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/these-founders-want-a-more-ethical-company-structure-for-startups\/\"><strong>Demand for ethics:<\/strong><\/a>\u00a0Regenerative community organism (RCO), a novel organizational model that aims to be a practical approach to integrating sustainability at the core of operations, is gaining steam in the startup world, Haje reports.<\/p>\n<h2>Bonus round<\/h2>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/foundry-group-is-shutting-down-and-wont-raise-another-fund\/?mrfhud=true\"><strong>Foundry Group shutters:<\/strong><\/a> Foundry Group, an 18-year-old venture firm with nearly $3.5 billion in assets under management, has quietly decided to shut down and not raise any more funds.<\/p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/apple-confirms-its-breaking-iphone-web-apps-in-the-eu-on-purpose\/?mrfhud=true\">Playing hardball:<\/a><\/strong> Apple has confirmed that it\u2019s breaking iPhone web apps in the European Union (EU) on purpose &#8212; blaming the new EU regulation, the Digital Markets Act, for the change.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Welcome, folks, to Week in Review (WiR), TechCrunch&#8217;s regular newsletter covering noteworthy happenings in the tech industry. This week, OpenAI stunned the blogosphere with the release of Sora, a new AI model that can generate videos in impressively high fidelity. We&#8217;ve seen video generators before. But what makes Sora unique is its understanding of time and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577152504"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577152504"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577152504"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577152504"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577152504"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577152504"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666192,"date":"2024-02-17T10:00:30","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T18:00:30","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666192"},"modified":"2024-02-16T08:31:33","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T16:31:33","slug":"y-combinator-mri-cancer","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/y-combinator-mri-cancer\/","title":{"rendered":"Y Combinator wants 100 times more MRI scans"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>L<\/em><br \/>\n<em>everaging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. This is good news: We need more companies attacking cancer from novel angles, including AI-enabled early detection. And who knows, maybe one of these will become a trillion-dollar company? \u2014 <\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/abracarioca\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><i>Anna<\/i><\/a><\/p>\n<h2>Scaling early cancer detection<\/h2>\n<p><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Y Combinator&#8217;s newest<\/span> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.ycombinator.com\/blog\/ycs-latest-request-for-startups\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">request for startups<\/a> (RFS) is well worth reading, and not just because it&#8217;s been a while since the incubator shared the ideas and categories its partners &#8220;would like to see more people working on.&#8221; As my colleague Sarah Perez noted, YC hadn&#8217;t updated its full list <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/\">since 2018<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"13H8g1hAa5\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/\">Y Combinator puts out a new call for startups in areas like AI, spatial computing, climate tech and more<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Y Combinator puts out a new call for startups in areas like AI, spatial computing, climate tech and more&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/embed\/#?secret=67NfdoNE3x#?secret=13H8g1hAa5\" data-secret=\"13H8g1hAa5\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Taken as a whole, YC&#8217;s RFS is a great way to sense the zeitgeist; the list includes AI of course, as well as climate tech, defense tech and more. But zooming in on individual requests is also a worthwhile exercise.<\/p>\n<p>One of the requests that captured my interest calls for &#8220;<a href=\"https:\/\/www.ycombinator.com\/rfs#a-way-to-end-cancer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a way to end cancer<\/a>.&#8221; Written by YC group partner Surbhi Sarna, a former medical device company CEO, it focuses on MRIs. &#8220;Since most cancers are now treatable if caught early enough,&#8221; she wrote, &#8220;this technology would dramatically reduce cancer deaths if rolled out widely and affordably.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>My first thought was that MRI startups already exist. Just a few days earlier, New York\u2013based Ezra raised a fresh round of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/rashishrivastava\/2024\/02\/10\/meet-the-bryan-johnson-approved-ai-full-body-mri-startup-that-just-raised-21-million\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$21 million<\/a> \u2014 and we are talking about a team that TechCrunch first covered <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/15\/ezra-cancer\/\">in 2018<\/a>. It has competitors, too, such as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/neko-health\/\">Neko<\/a>, backed by Spotify&#8217;s Daniel Ek, and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prenuvo.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Prenuvo<\/a>, which has a $2,500 full-body scan that was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/anafaguy\/2023\/08\/10\/kim-kardashian-promotes-2500-body-scan-heres-what-to-know-and-why-some-experts-warn-against-it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">promoted by Kim Kardashian<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>For Sarna, that price point is part of the problem, as it inherently limits scale, but it&#8217;s not the only one. &#8220;There is backlash from the medical community as MRIs also create incidental findings (or false positives) that cost our healthcare system valuable time and money to investigate.&#8221; The jury is <a href=\"https:\/\/english.elpais.com\/health\/2023-11-12\/mris-for-no-reason-the-health-debate-unleashed-by-kim-kardashian.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">still<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.newyorker.com\/science\/annals-of-medicine\/will-a-full-body-mri-scan-help-you-or-hurt-you\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">out<\/a> on whether they are beneficial or individuals, let alone society. But YC still hopes startups can help.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"IotSs5Vqf7\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/27\/how-to-get-into-y-combinator-dalton-caldwell\/\">How to get into Y Combinator, according to YC&#8217;s Dalton Caldwell<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;How to get into Y Combinator, according to YC&#8217;s Dalton Caldwell&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/27\/how-to-get-into-y-combinator-dalton-caldwell\/embed\/#?secret=TEqKwhxYdD#?secret=IotSs5Vqf7\" data-secret=\"IotSs5Vqf7\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;For this to work, the world would need to scale up the number of MRI scans it does by at least 100x. Doing that will require innovations in the MRI hardware, the AI algorithms to interpret scans and reduce false positives, and the business models and consumer marketing to make it a viable business.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Of course, companies like Ezra are also hoping to do some of this in-house. In its latest <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/pitch-deck-ezra-raise-vc-funding-ai-powered-mri-scans-2024-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pitch deck<\/a>, the startup boasted it &#8220;leverages Al at every step of the screening process.&#8221; But if others can contribute from other angles, I can see why YC would be interested \u2014 I am.<\/p>\n<h2>Co-working for biotech<\/h2>\n<p>Shared lab spaces have been a game changer for biotech startups, Nature <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nature.com\/articles\/d41586-024-00242-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a>. Of course, co-working isn&#8217;t new, but co-working labs provide their customers with much more than office space, saving them both time and money.<\/p>\n<p>This reminded me of Startup Battlefield alum <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/20\/parallel-health-takes-a-biotech-forward-approach-to-skincare-with-custom-phage-therapy\/\">Parallel Health<\/a> \u2014 its chief scientist officer Nathan Brown had mentioned shared labs in passing when we chatted at Disrupt. I noticed he had <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/johannesfruehauf?miniProfileUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_profile%3AACoAAADoJZkBAvPk1U07nSoBS9UlgFyU9fLsaWI\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">liked<\/a> a repost of Nature&#8217;s article, so I asked him for his thoughts. He confirmed that the skincare startup he co-founded had been using <a href=\"https:\/\/www.biolabs.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">BioLabs<\/a>&#8216; shared facilities in Los Angeles, and he highlighted some of the benefits of this concept:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>BioLabs has enabled us to cost-effectively build a consumer biotech product. They make the laboratory infrastructure available to us without having to spend our entire seed round on capital expenses like DNA sequencing machines, laminar flow hoods, and lab-grade freezers. We also save immense amounts of time at BioLabs, because they manage all aspects of environmental health and safety as well as infrastructure management. Maybe most importantly, they create a thriving culture of innovation where startups can collaborate easily and learn from each other.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>While this may read as a local endorsement, startups don&#8217;t have to be based in California to leverage this trend. BioLabs itself is a franchise that has expanded to a dozen locations, and similar things could likely be said of many competing facilities around the world. However, a founder interviewed by Nature, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.accurehealth.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Accure Health<\/a> CEO Jessica Sang, shared a word of caution: Some labs are better equipped and wider-ranging than others. &#8220;If you\u2019re thinking about starting a company, try to visit a few just to see which one is the best.&#8221;<\/p>\n<h2>Virtual data rooms<\/h2>\n<p>Virtual data rooms are another important resource for biotech startups. Calling them &#8220;the unsung hero of biotech financing,&#8221; and noting that they can also be helpful in business development talks, a16z published a <a href=\"https:\/\/a16z.com\/virtual-data-rooms-the-unsung-hero-of-biotech-financing\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">guide<\/a> on what biotech teams should and shouldn&#8217;t put in their data rooms.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Leveraging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. This is good news: We need more companies attacking cancer from novel angles.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574450,"featured_media":2562690,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"4d5c5bec-ae35-3bf8-af99-284ce6218c33","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"","apple_news_api_id":"","apple_news_api_modified_at":"","apple_news_api_revision":"","apple_news_api_share_url":"","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577030454,20429],"tags":[576715346,35186,577189240,576936589,576765839,66455],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796356],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>Y Combinator wants 100 times more MRI scans | TechCrunch<\/title>\n<meta name=\"description\" content=\"Leveraging resources such as virtual data rooms and shared labs makes it easier for biotech startups to grow. name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[]]}},{"id":2666800,"date":"2024-02-17T09:00:30","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T17:00:30","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666800"},"modified":"2024-02-17T09:50:36","modified_gmt":"2024-02-17T17:50:36","slug":"groover-independent-artists-song-discovery","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/groover-independent-artists-song-discovery\/","title":{"rendered":"Groover connects artists with tastemakers to help them find their audience"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Last Monday, I discovered Walter the Producer, a Boston-based indie musician. His music isn&#8217;t on any of the playlists I follow, and he has less than 150,000 monthly listeners on Spotify. If I hadn&#8217;t searched for <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=IgaV_p4Ni_w\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">his song<\/a> on Shazam while I was 2,000 miles away from home in a brewery in Phoenix, I probably wouldn&#8217;t have ever found him.<\/p>\n<p>Finding new music has become somewhat of a game. Walter the Producer even pokes fun at this, too; his Spotify artist bio just says, &#8220;If you gatekeep me i will hunt you down.&#8221; Deep-pocketed artists have always had a leg up on independent musicians when it comes to promotion. But algorithm changes at Spotify, the rise of viral TikTok songs and strategy shifts at places like Pitchfork and Rolling Stone have made it significantly more challenging.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s easier now than ever to create music. This dynamic is what inspired the founders of Groover. The Paris-based startup launched in 2018 as a platform to help independent artists promote themselves by letting them submit music to individual curators who can provide feedback and amplify music they think is good. Romain Palmieri, co-founder and CEO of Groover, said that he and his two co-founders started the company to help fix the promotion issues they&#8217;ve all come across in their respective music careers.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Independent artists have more access to music creation, which is great and creates more creativity, but the main challenge for artists is how can you promote the music and get heard by the right people and get the right curation by the right people,&#8221; Palmieri said. &#8220;We wanted to build something that could solve this.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Groover just raised an $8 million Series A round led by OneRagtime, Techmind, Trind and Mozza Angels. Palmieri said that the company plans to use the funding to continue expanding into the U.S. \u2014 its largest market already \u2014 and to add new features for artists, including coaching and promotion resources.<\/p>\n<p>The business model for this company stands out. The 3,000 and growing music curators on Groover set their own price, and each transaction gets split with half of the money going to the curator and half to Groover. Palmieri said that if a curator doesn&#8217;t listen to a song within seven days, the musician gets their money back, but that 90% of requests get answered in that timeframe.<\/p>\n<p>While I like the concept of artists getting to have these more direct relationships with these different curators, it bums me out that pay-to-play has become the best option for these independent artists. The curators who work with Groover aren&#8217;t just promoting music they like but rather music they like that they were also paid to listen to.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>But! I also get that music journalism is shrinking as the number of independent musicians continues to rapidly scale. Solutions are good even if I don&#8217;t find them perfect. The fact that artists get to choose who they work with on Groover, the outreach is relatively inexpensive, and the response rate is pretty high makes this seem like the most artist-friendly approach that isn&#8217;t earned promotion.<\/p>\n<p>Palmieri added that the majority of independent artists just do not have better or more cost-effective options. They can either pitch music publications relentlessly with no measured chance of getting noticed or pay up for PR, which doesn&#8217;t necessarily ensure more success.<\/p>\n<p>This system works better for music curators, too, Palmieri said. They also often have trouble finding the diamonds in the rough of the ever-growing sea of new music. Groover&#8217;s system helps them get paid for their work more directly while making their jobs a bit easier.<\/p>\n<p>I&#8217;m glad to see someone working to fix this issue because as a listener, finding new music has been noticeably more difficult. I&#8217;ve seen numerous tweets, had numerous conversations with friends that show this issue is felt across the board. Only one person still posts in the pretentiously named Music Aficionados Facebook Group that my friends and I started in high school to share new music.<\/p>\n<p>Groover isn&#8217;t the only startup looking to help small musicians, either. GigFinesse is another startup that helps both musicians and venues better book gigs with a more streamlined booking and payments system.<\/p>\n<p>I liked GigFinesse in the same way I like Groover; that is, I like startups that offer clear solutions for both sides of the table. Both of these startups help the artists but they also help the folks in the industry needed to get those artists off the ground. The community needs each other to be able to thrive. Every musician starts somewhere.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Groover offers a platform for independent musicians to connect with music curators and be able to better promote themselves.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574554,"featured_media":2666804,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"340a4181-da63-39ce-b421-806e8a9fb775","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-17T17:00:42Z","apple_news_api_id":"c81b29a1-a3e1-4fe1-acda-90c55f35100f","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-17T17:50:45Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AyBspoaPhT-Gs2pDFXzUQDw","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577030456,20429,577030455],"tags":[18,1641,449557042,202],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[577037503,577037509],"yoast_head":"<!-- name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_regions_tax\/577037509"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_regions_tax"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_regions_tax"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_regions_tax\/577037507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_regions_tax=577037509"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tc_regions_tax=577037509"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2665704,"date":"2024-02-17T07:24:19","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T15:24:19","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2665704"},"modified":"2024-02-17T07:24:19","modified_gmt":"2024-02-17T15:24:19","slug":"women-in-ai-irene-solaiman-head-of-global-policy-at-hugging-face","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/women-in-ai-irene-solaiman-head-of-global-policy-at-hugging-face\/","title":{"rendered":"Women In AI: Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">series of interviews<\/a> focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more profiles <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Irene Solaiman began her career in AI as a researcher and public policy manager at OpenAI, where she led a new approach to the release of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/02\/17\/openai-text-generator-dangerous\/\">GPT-2<\/a>, a predecessor to ChatGPT. After serving as an AI policy manager at Zillow for nearly a year, she joined Hugging Face as the head of global policy. Her responsibilities there range from building and leading company AI policy globally to conducting socio-technical research.<\/p>\n<p>Solaiman also advises the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), the professional association for electronics engineering, on AI issues, and is a recognized AI expert at the intergovernmental Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).<\/p>\n<h2>Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face<\/h2>\n<h3>Briefly, how did you get your start in AI? What attracted you to the field?<\/h3>\n<p>A thoroughly nonlinear career path is commonplace in AI. My budding interest started in the same way many teenagers with awkward social skills find their passions: through sci-fi media. I originally studied human rights policy and then took computer science courses, as I viewed AI as a means of working on human rights and building a better future. Being able to do technical research and lead policy in a field with so many unanswered questions and untaken paths keeps my work exciting.<\/p>\n<h3>What work are you most proud of (in the AI field)?<\/h3>\n<p>I\u2019m most proud of when my expertise resonates with people across the AI field, especially my writing on release considerations in the complex landscape of AI system releases and openness. Seeing my paper on an <a href=\"https:\/\/arxiv.org\/pdf\/2302.04844.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AI Release Gradient frame technical deployment<\/a> prompt discussions among scientists and used in government reports is affirming &#8212; and a good sign I\u2019m working in the right direction! Personally, some of the work I\u2019m most motivated by is on cultural value alignment, which is dedicated to ensuring that systems work best for the cultures in which they&#8217;re deployed. With my incredible co-author and now dear friend, Christy Dennison, working on a <a href=\"https:\/\/arxiv.org\/pdf\/2106.10328.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Process for Adapting Language Models to Society<\/a> was a whole of heart (and many debugging hours) project that has shaped safety and alignment work today.<\/p>\n<h3>How do you navigate the challenges of the male-dominated tech industry, and, by extension, the male-dominated AI industry?<\/h3>\n<p>I\u2019ve found, and am still finding, my people &#8212; from working with incredible company leadership who care deeply about the same issues that I prioritize to great research co-authors with whom I can start every working session with a mini therapy session. Affinity groups are hugely helpful in building community and sharing tips. Intersectionality is important to highlight here; my communities of Muslim and BIPOC researchers are continually inspiring.<\/p>\n<h3>What advice would you give to women seeking to enter the AI field?<\/h3>\n<p>Have a support group whose success is your success. In youth terms, I believe this is a &#8220;girl\u2019s girl.&#8221; The same women and allies I entered this field with are my favorite coffee dates and late-night panicked calls ahead of a deadline. One of the best pieces of career advice I\u2019ve read was from Arvind Narayan on the platform formerly known as Twitter establishing the &#8220;Liam Neeson Principle&#8221;of not being the smartest of them all, but having a particular set of skills.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<h3>What are some of the most pressing issues facing AI as it evolves?<\/h3>\n<p>The most pressing issues themselves evolve, so the meta answer is: International coordination for safer systems for all peoples. Peoples who use and are affected by systems, even in the same country, have varying preferences and ideas of what is safest for themselves. And the issues that arise will depend not only on how AI evolves, but on the environment into which they&#8217;re deployed; safety priorities and our definitions of capability differ regionally, such as a higher threat of cyberattacks to critical infrastructure in more digitized economies.<\/p>\n<h3>What are some issues AI users should be aware of?<\/h3>\n<p>Technical solutions rarely, if ever, address risks and harms holistically. While there are steps users can take to increase their AI literacy, it\u2019s important to invest in a multitude of safeguards for risks as they evolve. For example, I\u2019m excited about more research into watermarking as a technical tool, and we also need coordinated policymaker guidance on generated content distribution, especially on social media platforms.<\/p>\n<h3>What is the best way to responsibly build AI?<\/h3>\n<p>With the peoples affected and constantly re-evaluating our methods for assessing and implementing safety techniques. Both beneficial applications and potential harms constantly evolve and require iterative feedback. The means by which we improve AI safety should be collectively examined as a field. The most popular evaluations for models in 2024 are much more robust than those I was running in 2019. Today, I\u2019m much more bullish about technical evaluations than I am about red-teaming. I find human evaluations extremely high utility, but as more evidence arises of the mental burden and disparate costs of human feedback, I\u2019m increasingly bullish about standardizing evaluations.<\/p>\n<h3>How can investors better push for responsible AI?<\/h3>\n<p>They already are! I\u2019m glad to see many investors and venture capital companies actively engaging in safety and policy conversations, including via open letters and Congressional testimonies. I\u2019m eager to hear more from investors\u2019 expertise on what stimulates small businesses across sectors, especially as we\u2019re seeing more AI use from fields outside the core tech industries.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>To give AI-focused women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a series of interviews focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more \/ Yoast SEO Premium plugin. -->","yoast_head_json":{"title":"Women in AI | TechCrunch","description":"Read the latest news about Women in AI on TechCrunch","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/women-in-ai-solaiman\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"Women in AI | TechCrunch","og_description":"Read the latest news about Women in AI on TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/women-in-ai\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/women-in-ai\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/women-in-ai\/","name":"Women in AI | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"description":"Read the latest news about Women in AI on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577231038"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577231038"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577231038"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2663822,"date":"2024-02-17T07:23:04","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T15:23:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822"},"modified":"2024-02-18T08:22:06","modified_gmt":"2024-02-18T16:22:06","slug":"the-women-in-ai-making-a-difference","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/the-women-in-ai-making-a-difference\/","title":{"rendered":"The women in AI making a difference"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">To give AI-focused<\/span> women academics and others their well-deserved &#8212; and overdue &#8212; time in the spotlight, TechCrunch is launching a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">series of interviews<\/a> focusing on remarkable women who&#8217;ve contributed to the AI revolution. We&#8217;ll publish several pieces throughout the year as the AI boom continues, highlighting key work that often goes unrecognized. Read more profiles <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2663822&amp;preview=true\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>As a reader, if you see a name we&#8217;ve missed and feel should be on the list, please email us and we&#8217;ll seek to add them. Here&#8217;s some key people you should know:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2665704&amp;preview=true\">Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/18\/women-in-ai-eva-maydell-member-of-european-parliament-and-eu-ai-act-advisor\/\">Eva Maydell, member of European Parliament and EU AI Act advisor<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2>The gender gap in AI<\/h2>\n<p>In a New York Times <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2023\/12\/03\/technology\/ai-key-figures.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">piece<\/a> late last year, the Gray Lady broke down how the current boom in AI came to be &#8212; highlighting many of the usual suspects like Sam Altman, Elon Musk and Larry Page. The journalism went viral \u2013 not for what was reported, but instead for what it failed to mention: women.<\/p>\n<p>The Times&#8217; list featured 12 men &#8212; most of them leaders of AI or tech companies. Many had no training or education, formal or otherwise, in AI.<\/p>\n<p>Contrary to the Times\u2019 suggestion, the AI craze didn&#8217;t start with Musk sitting adjacent to Page at a mansion in the Bay. It began long before that, with academics, regulators, ethicists and hobbyists working tirelessly in relative obscurity to build the foundations for the AI and GenAI systems we have today.<\/p>\n<p>Elaine Rich, a retired computer scientist formerly at the University of Texas at Austin, published one of the first textbooks on AI in 1983, and later went on to become the director of a corporate AI lab in 1988. Harvard professor Cynthia Dwork made waves decades ago in the fields of AI fairness, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/24\/implement-differential-privacy-to-power-up-data-sharing-and-cooperation\/\">differential privacy<\/a> and distributed computing. And Cynthia Breazeal, a roboticist and professor at MIT and the co-founder of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/03\/04\/the-lonely-death-of-jibo-the-social-robot\/\">Jibo<\/a>, the robotics startup, worked to develop one of the earliest &#8220;social robots,&#8221; Kismet, in the late &#8217;90s and early 2000s.<\/p>\n<p>Despite the many ways in which women have advanced AI tech, they make up a tiny sliver of the global AI workforce. According to a 2021 Stanford <a href=\"https:\/\/hai.stanford.edu\/news\/ai-index-diversity-report-unmoving-needle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">study<\/a>, just 16% of tenure-track faculty focused on AI are women. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.weforum.org\/agenda\/2021\/08\/5-ways-increase-women-working-ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">In a separate study<\/a> released the same year by the World Economic Forum, the co-authors find that women only hold 26% of analytics-related and AI positions.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>In worse news, the gender gap in AI is widening &#8212; not narrowing.<\/p>\n<p>Nesta, the U.K.&#8217;s innovation agency for social good, conducted <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nesta.org.uk\/press-release\/gender-diversity-crisis-ai-less-14-ai-researchers-are-women-numbers-decreasing-over-last-10-years\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a 2019 analysis<\/a> that concluded that the proportion of AI academic papers co-authored by at least one woman hadn&#8217;t improved since the 1990s. As of 2019, just 13.8% of the AI research papers on Arxiv.org, a repository for preprint scientific papers, were authored or co-authored by women, with the numbers steadily decreasing over the preceding decade.<\/p>\n<h2>Reasons for disparity<\/h2>\n<p>The reasons for the disparity are many. But <a href=\"https:\/\/www2.deloitte.com\/content\/dam\/Deloitte\/cn\/Documents\/deloitte-analytics\/cn-consulting-women-in-ai-en.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a Deloitte survey of women in AI<\/a> highlights a few of the more prominent (and obvious) ones, including judgment from male peers and discrimination as a result of not fitting into established male-dominated molds in AI.<\/p>\n<p>It starts in college: 78% of women responding to the Deloitte survey said they didn&#8217;t have a chance to intern in AI or machine learning while they were undergraduates. Over half (58%) said they ended up leaving at least one employer because of how men and women were treated differently, while 73% considered leaving the tech industry altogether due to unequal pay and an inability to advance in their careers.<\/p>\n<p>The lack of women is hurting the AI field.<\/p>\n<p>Nesta&#8217;s analysis found that women are more likely than men to consider societal, ethical and political implications in their work on AI &#8212; which isn&#8217;t surprising considering women live in a world where they&#8217;re belittled on the basis of their gender, products in the market have been designed for men, and women with children are often expected to balance work with their role as primary caregivers.<\/p>\n<p>With any luck, TechCrunch&#8217;s humble contribution &#8212; a series on accomplished women in AI &#8212; will help move the needle in the right direction. But there&#8217;s clearly a lot of work to be done.<\/p>\n<p>The women we profile share many suggestions for those who wish to grow and evolve the AI field for the better. But a common thread runs throughout: strong mentorship, commitment and leading by example. Organizations can affect change by enacting policies &#8212; hiring, education or otherwise &#8212; that elevate women already in, or looking to break into, the AI industry. And decision-makers in positions of power can wield that power to push for more diverse, supportive workplaces for women.<\/p>\n<p>Change won&#8217;t happen overnight. But every revolution begins with a small step.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>As a part of a multi-part series, TechCrunch is highlighting women innovators \u2014 from academics to policymakers \u2014in the field of
