| TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"about":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"description":"Read the latest news about women on TechCrunch","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/women\/#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"BreadcrumbList","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/women\/#breadcrumb","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"women"}]},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/598"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=598"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=598"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=598"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=598"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=598"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666502,"date":"2024-02-17T05:00:10","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T13:00:10","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666502"},"modified":"2024-02-16T11:08:51","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T19:08:51","slug":"why-ransomware-makes-so-much-money","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/17\/why-ransomware-makes-so-much-money\/","title":{"rendered":"Why are ransomware gangs making so much money?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">For many organizations<\/span> and startups, 2023 was a rough year financially, with companies struggling to raise money and others making cuts to survive. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ransomware and extortion gangs<\/a>, on the other hand, had a record-breaking year in earnings, if recent reports are anything to go by.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s hardly surprising when you look at the state of the ransomware landscape. Last year saw hackers continue to evolve their tactics to become scrappier and more extreme in efforts to pressure victims into paying their increasingly exorbitant ransom demands. This escalation in tactics, along with the fact that governments have stopped short of banning ransom payments, led to 2023 becoming the most lucrative year yet for ransomware gangs.<\/p>\n<h2>The billion-dollar cybercrime business<\/h2>\n<p>According to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.chainalysis.com\/blog\/ransomware-2024\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">new data from crypto forensics startup Chainalysis<\/a>, known ransomware payments almost doubled in 2023 to surpass the $1 billion mark, calling the year a \u201cmajor comeback for ransomware.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s the highest figure ever observed, and almost double the amount of known ransom payments tracked in 2022. But Chainalysis said the actual figure is likely far higher than the $1.1 billion in ransom payments it has witnessed so far.<\/p>\n<p>There\u2019s a glimmer of good news, though. While 2023 was overall a bumper year for ransomware gangs, other <a href=\"https:\/\/www.coveware.com\/blog\/2024\/1\/25\/new-ransomware-reporting-requirements-kick-in-as-victims-increasingly-avoid-paying\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hacker-watchers observed a drop in payments<\/a> toward the end of the year.<\/p>\n<p>This drop is a result of improved cyber defenses and resiliency, along with the growing sentiment that most victim organizations don&#8217;t trust hackers to keep their promises or delete any stolen data as they claim. \u201cThis has led to better guidance to victims and fewer payments for intangible assurances,\u201d according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.coveware.com\/blog\/2024\/1\/25\/new-ransomware-reporting-requirements-kick-in-as-victims-increasingly-avoid-paying\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ransomware remediation company Coveware<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h2>Record-breaking ransoms<\/h2>\n<p>While more ransomware victims are refusing to line the pockets of hackers, ransomware gangs are compensating for this drop in earnings by increasing the number of victims they target.<\/p>\n<p>Take the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/25\/moveit-mass-hack-by-the-numbers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">MOVEit campaign<\/a>. This huge hack saw the prolific Russia-linked Clop ransomware gang mass-exploit a never-before-seen vulnerability in the widely used MOVEit Transfer software to steal data from the systems of more than 2,700 victim organizations. Many of the victims are known to have paid the hacking group in efforts to prevent the publication of sensitive data.<\/p>\n<p>While it\u2019s impossible to know exactly how much money the mass-hack made for the ransomware group, Chainalysis said in its report that Clop&#8217;s MOVEit campaign amassed over $100 million in ransom payments, and accounted for almost half of all ransomware value received in June and July 2023 during the height of this mass-hack.<\/p>\n<p>MOVEit was by no means the only money-making campaign of 2023.<\/p>\n<p>In September, casino and entertainment giant <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/caesars-entertainment-data-breach-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Caesars paid roughly $15 million<\/a> to hackers to prevent the disclosure of customer data stolen during an August cyberattack.<\/p>\n<p>This multimillion-dollar payment perhaps illustrates why ransomware actors continue to make so much money: the Caesars attack barely made it into the news, while a subsequent <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/mgm-cyberattack-outage-scattered-spider\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attack on hotel giant MGM Resorts<\/a> \u2014 which has so far cost the company $100 million to recover from \u2014 dominated headlines for weeks. MGM\u2019s refusal to pay the ransom led to the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/mgm-resorts-admits-hackers-stole-customers-personal-data-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hackers&#8217; release of sensitive MGM customer data<\/a>, including names, Social Security numbers and passport details. Caesars \u2014 outwardly at least \u2014 appeared largely unscathed, even if by its own admission <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/caesars-entertainment-data-breach-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">could not guarantee that the ransomware gang would delete<\/a> the company&#8217;s stolen data.<\/p>\n<h2>Escalating threats<\/h2>\n<p>For many organizations, like Caesars, paying the ransom demand seems like the easiest option to avoid a public relations nightmare. But as the ransom money dries up, ransomware and extortion gangs are upping the ante and resorting to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">escalating tactics and extreme threats<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>In December, for example, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.databreaches.net\/recent-attacks-on-fred-hutch-and-integris-is-attempting-to-extort-patients-directly-becoming-the-new-normal\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hackers reportedly tried to pressure a cancer hospital into paying a ransom demand<\/a> by threatening to &#8220;swat&#8221; its patients. Swatting incidents rely on malicious callers falsely claiming a fake real-world threat to life, prompting the response of armed police officers.<\/p>\n<p>We also saw the notorious Alphv (known as BlackCat) ransomware gang <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/new-sec-data-breach-disclosure-rules\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">weaponize the U.S. government\u2019s new data breach disclosure rules<\/a> against MeridianLink, one of the gang&#8217;s many victims. Alphv accused MeridianLink of allegedly failing to publicly disclose what the gang called \u201ca significant breach compromising customer data and operational information,\u201d for which the gang took credit.<\/p>\n<h2>No ban on ransom payments<\/h2>\n<p>Another reason ransomware continues to be lucrative for hackers is that while not advised, there&#8217;s nothing stopping organizations paying up \u2014 unless, of course, the hackers <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/11\/02\/government-sanctions-ransomware-effective\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">have been sanctioned<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">To pay or not to pay the ransom<\/a> is a controversial subject. Ransomware remediator Coveware suggests that if a ransom payment ban was imposed in the U.S. or any other highly victimized country, companies would likely stop reporting these incidents to the authorities, reversing past cooperation between victims and law enforcement agencies. The company also predicts that a ransom payments ban would lead to the overnight creation of a large illegal market for facilitating ransomware payments.<\/p>\n<p>Others, however, believe a blanket ban is the only way to ensure ransomware hackers can\u2019t continue to line their pockets \u2014 at least in the short term.<\/p>\n<p>Allan Liska, a threat intelligence analyst at Recorded Future, has long opposed banning ransom payments \u2014 but now believes that for as long as ransom payments remain lawful, cybercriminals will do whatever it takes to collect them.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cI\u2019ve resisted the idea of blanket bans on ransom payments for years, but I think that has to change,&#8221; Liska told TechCrunch. &#8220;Ransomware is getting worse, not just in the number of attacks but in the aggressive nature of the attacks and the groups behind them.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>\u201cA ban on ransom payments will be painful and, if history is any guide, will likely lead to a short-term increase in ransomware attacks, but it seems like this is the only solution that has a chance of long-term success at this point,\u201d said Liska.<\/p>\n<p>While more victims are realizing that paying the hackers cannot guarantee the safety of their data, it\u2019s clear that these financially motivated cybercriminals <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/03\/fbi-most-wanted-russian-hacker-reveals-why-he-burned-his-passport\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">aren&#8217;t giving up their lavish lifestyles anytime soon<\/a>. Until then, ransomware attacks will remain a major money-making exercise for the hackers behind them.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Read more on TechCrunch:<\/strong><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Why ransomware victims can\u2019t stop paying off hackers<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/11\/02\/government-sanctions-ransomware-effective\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Do government sanctions against ransomware groups work?<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/12\/18\/why-extortion-is-the-new-ransomware-threat\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Why extortion is the new ransomware threat<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>For many organizations and startups, 2023 was a rough year financially, with companies struggling to raise money and others making cuts to survive. Ransomware and extortion gangs, on the other hand, had a record-breaking year in earnings, if recent reports are anything to go by. It&#8217;s hardly surprising when you look at the state of News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/192933"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=192933"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=192933"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666950,"date":"2024-02-16T22:12:36","date_gmt":"2024-02-17T06:12:36","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666950"},"modified":"2024-02-17T13:16:16","modified_gmt":"2024-02-17T21:16:16","slug":"a-peek-at-how-things-work-today-inside-alphabets-7-billion-growth-stage-investing-arm-capitalg","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/a-peek-at-how-things-work-today-inside-alphabets-7-billion-growth-stage-investing-arm-capitalg\/","title":{"rendered":"A peek inside Alphabet&#8217;s $7 billion growth-stage investing arm, CapitalG"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Almost a year ago, Alphabet\u2019s growth stage venture arm, <a href=\"https:\/\/capitalg.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CapitalG<\/a>, named partner Laela Sturdy as its new head, just as the unit&#8217;s founder, David Lawee, stepped down.<\/p>\n<p>Few were surprised Sturdy was promoted to the post. She joined Google in 2007 in a marketing role, was pulled into a number of departments in the following years, and when CapitalG was launched in 2013, she was recruited by Lawlee, who told CNBC in 2021, &#8220;I kind of made it a point to know who all the stars were inside of Google, and Laela\u2019s name came up a lot.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Of course, for many investors, the last year has been among the toughest in their career. We wondered if the same is true for Sturdy, a former college basketball star who is quick to note that 60% of her team comes from diverse or underrepresented backgrounds. To find out more, we reached her earlier this week at CapitalG&#8217;s bright, airy office in San Francisco&#8217;s Ferry Building; excerpts of our chat are edited lightly for length and clarity below.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Belated congratulations on taking over the helm. How does your management style differ from that of your predecessor, David?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I&#8217;m still leading investments and still on a bunch of boards, but I&#8217;ve loved being able to also put increasing attention on the team and figure out how we can continue to build out the firm. There&#8217;s [now] many more incredible investors that we have at CapitalG.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You have around 50 people on your team; how many of these are investors versus otherwise?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Our model is to find ways that Google and Alphabet can help our portfolio companies, so not only the individuals on this team, but to give you an idea [of what I mean], over the last couple of years, we&#8217;ve had over 3500 different senior advisors inside of Alphabet help partner with our portfolio companies [to help with] pricing analysis, scaling infrastructure, marketing and setting up sales incentives. There are all these different technical and business questions that come up for growth-stage companies, which is where we specialize.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><strong>Access to 3500 different senior advisors! How does that work?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>An example is over the last couple of years, we\u2019ve partnered with the Google training team who does AI and ML training for Google engineers. We said \u2018Hey, this training is really effective and gets really high ratings internally.\u2019 And we have a lot of our portfolio companies asking us, \u2018How can we up level the talent of our engineering and our organizations and get them ready to fully take advantage of the trends in AI?\u2019 So we partnered with the training team and got our portfolio companies access to the exact same training, and we\u2019ve now had hundreds of engineers inside our portfolio go through that training. I worked at Google for a long time before I came to CapitalG, and one of the amazing things about the culture of Google from the beginning is a real culture of knowledge sharing.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The market for AI talent is so competitive. What can you tell portfolio companies that might feel nervous about the information that&#8217;s going into and out of Alphabet through you?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Everything is opt-in from the portfolio companies\u2019 standpoint. We don&#8217;t share anything; we operate totally separately. We don&#8217;t share any portfolio company data with Alphabet and we don&#8217;t share any Alphabet data back to the portfolio companies. We exist as the intermediary to find win-wins where they exist.<\/p>\n<p>As an example, [Google Cloud] has been an incredible go-to-market partner [and] all the other cloud providers are also important and great partners, so we don\u2019t push anything on anyone. We help facilitate the right introductions and marketing partnerships and product discussions where it&#8217;s relevant.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How are decisions made inside CapitalG? Do you have final say over who sees a check?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We have an investment committee [composed of] myself and three other general partners who are really incredible investors. For example, my partner Gene Frantz, who I&#8217;ve been working with for the last 10 years \u2013 since almost the beginning of CapitalG \u2013 is a longtime investor who was at TPG and other places before [joining the outfit]. So we&#8217;ve built a GP bench that&#8217;s really strong, and these GPs bring deals to our investment committee, and we make the decision as a committee.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How many bets per year are you making? And what size checks are you writing?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We typically invest between $50 million and $200 million in each company. We&#8217;re very thesis driven, so we spend a lot of time going deep on sectors . . and we&#8217;re investing in about seven or eight new companies a year and then typically [many] more follow-on [rounds] for our existing portfolio.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How much of a company do you aim to own?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We\u2019re flexible on ownership percentage. What we&#8217;re thinking about is our money-on-money returns in these companies. For example, I led the Series D round in Stripe back in 2017. I think that was a $9 billion valuation. [We closed] a recent AI investment that was on the earlier side \u2013 it had a sub $500 million valuation \u2013 so we&#8217;re very focused on the market, how much we think the business is differentiated, and whether we can invest a significant amount of capital to scale.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What are your cash-on-cash returns?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We don&#8217;t share those publicly. We don&#8217;t share any of the returns publicly.<\/p>\n<p><strong>At $9 billion, you&#8217;re going to do great with that investment in Stripe, whose valuation ran all the way up to $95 billion before it was reset at $50 billion last year. Do you think that valuation swing was in response to market trends or its performance?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Stripe is an incredible company and [tackling] absolutely one of the biggest market opportunities out there, so I&#8217;m very bullish on their performance to date and all that&#8217;s ahead. When you look at any valuations, public or private, across the last 18 to 24 months, all of them had some sort of reset based coming out of the COVID . . .so I wouldn&#8217;t read anything into the company\u2019s performance.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Does Alphabet allocate a discrete fund to you every year?\u00a0<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Yes, we invest out of discrete funds, so yearly annual funds.<\/p>\n<p><strong>How big are they?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We have $7 billion in assets under management [dating back to 2013].<\/p>\n<p><strong>So you have a lot of money in a market where others have less. With the IPO market stalled and other late-stage investors investing less, are you buying up secondary shares?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We&#8217;re very focused on partnerships with the CEO and the management team. We will only invest if we have engagement with the CEO and we have direct data from the company. Our model is we want to be the best partners to these founders so that they refer us to the next best companies down the line.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What secondary shares have you bought?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I won&#8217;t share specific companies because that hasn&#8217;t been [publicly disclosed by the companies]. And a lot of secondary sales end up structured as primary anyway. But the broader trend that you&#8217;re referring to is interesting because it is early-stage investors looking for liquidity. And I think that\u2019s right in line with our strategy of finding the best growth-stage companies and at what we believe is very early in their long-term compounding [trajectory], so we&#8217;re super excited to get on the cap table of those types of companies. . . Our strategy is to partner with these companies early and then hold them for a long period of time.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You do eventually distribute shares back to Alphabet, though.<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We definitely distribute, but I\u2019d say we have a long-term orientation.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Does Alphabet really care if you deliver returns? Are these bets mostly strategic?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We focus on delivering returns, and we focus on the mission of using the expertise and experience of Google and Alphabet to be world-class partners to these generational tech companies.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Google is obviously going big on AI. Tell me a bit about your own AI strategy.<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We\u2019re as excited about AI as everyone else. We have a really wonderful team of people focused on it within CapitalG, and that&#8217;s another area where we have some really great advisors within Google who have enabled us to lean into even more technical bets. Cybersecurity is a good example here. We were in CrowdStrike in the Series B when they had $15 million in revenue or something, and a big part of making some of those early cybersecurity bets was a differentiated technical point of view. So we&#8217;re bringing that same rigor to the AI space.<\/p>\n<p>One of the things that we think is really interesting in the AI space is, when we look across enterprise use cases, we actually think a lot of the incumbents are quite well-positioned, because they have distribution, they have customers, they have workflows . . .so where we&#8217;ve been looking a bit more is places where there&#8217;s real technical differentiation and where workflow and existing distribution is less important. One company that we\u2019ve backed that we believe has a strong, technical differentiation is <a href=\"https:\/\/capitalg.com\/insights\/magic-reimagining-software-engineering-with-ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Magic<\/a>, which is focused on building an AI software engineer.<\/p>\n<p><strong>You\u2019re also on the board of Duolingo, which parted ways with 10% of its contractors last month. A spokesperson said at the time that the company didn&#8217;t really need as many people, in part because of AI. Is that something that you&#8217;re seeing across your portfolio companies?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I won&#8217;t comment on Duolingo specifically, but I will say that across our portfolio companies, they are looking at how AI can enhance the customer experience, and enhance their other systems and processes. I think there&#8217;s a lot of surprise and delight around that. There&#8217;s a lot of rethinking of the marketing stack. There&#8217;s a lot of rethinking of customer support and services. We&#8217;re still in very early innings. But the same way I see enterprise customers excited to experiment with how they can use AI in their workflow, I see startup and growth-stage companies really excited to experiment with how they can use AI to rethink how they&#8217;re building the organization and get all of their employees focused on the most high-value opportunities. There&#8217;s a lot of interesting work happening there.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Almost a year ago, Alphabet\u2019s growth stage venture arm, CapitalG, named partner Laela Sturdy as its new head, just as the unit&#8217;s founder, David Lawee, stepped down. Few were surprised Sturdy was promoted to the post. She joined Google in 2007 in a marketing role, was pulled into a number of departments in the following [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":89646803,"featured_media":2666952,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"fbd65e67-8543-359b-8159-033187c2bb3a","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-17T06:12:46Z","apple_news_api_id":"9219d5a8-19da-4486-91e3-373c23ba6cb9","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-17T21:16:12Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAABg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AkhnVqBnaRIaR4zc8I7psuQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577030455],"tags":[],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- and SpaceX are quietly trying to demolish national labor law"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Amazon alleged in a <a href=\"https:\/\/aboutblaw.com\/bcMF\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">legal filing<\/a> published Friday morning that the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) is unconstitutional. SpaceX and Trader Joe&#8217;s &#8212; companies that, like Amazon, have <a href=\"https:\/\/jacobin.com\/2024\/02\/trader-joes-nlrb-new-deal\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">repeatedly<\/a>\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/18\/amazon-fined-by-regulators-for-unsafe-warehouse-work-conditions\/\">faced<\/a>\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/12\/01\/amazon-broke-federal-labor-law-by-racially-disparaging-union-leaders.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">labor<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/03\/spacex-wrongly-fired-eight-activist-employee-us-labor-board-alleges\/\">law<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/05\/lawsuit-alleges-discriminatory-pay-schemes-at-spacex\/\">violations<\/a> from the federal agency &#8212; have recently made <a href=\"https:\/\/www.law360.com\/articles\/1782460\/spacex-says-nlrb-is-unconstitutional-in-labor-suit-s-wake\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">similar<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/news.bloomberglaw.com\/daily-labor-report\/trader-joes-follows-spacex-in-arguing-nlrb-is-unconstitutional\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attacks<\/a>\u00a0that threaten national worker protections.<\/p>\n<p>This is just Amazon&#8217;s latest <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/nlrb-amazon-union-busting-staten-island-jfk8-warehouse-2022-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attempt<\/a> to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2021\/03\/16\/technology\/amazon-unions-virginia.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">block union organizing<\/a> in its fulfillment centers. But this time, these companies aren&#8217;t just limiting the rights of their own workers. If these threats against the NLRB keep moving forward, American workers could lose workplace protections that they&#8217;ve had for almost a century.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It&#8217;s a crock of s&#8211;t,&#8221; said Seth Goldstein, the legal counsel for Trader Joe&#8217;s United and the Amazon Labor Union. &#8220;I don&#8217;t believe any of it, and I think it&#8217;s just a cover to bust unions.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Amazon claims that the NLRB&#8217;s structure is unconstitutional because administrative law judges are &#8220;insulated from presidential oversight,&#8221; thus violating the separation of powers. The company also argues against the structure of NLRB itself, as well as its ability to fine a company for unfair labor practices after a hearing, rather than a full jury trial.<\/p>\n<p>Amazon did not respond to request for comment.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Judges need protections to remain independent, just like federal judges. You can&#8217;t remove federal judges,&#8221; Goldstein told TechCrunch. The complaint about a lack of jury trials for companies may seem less dubious, but Goldstein still thinks it&#8217;s a stretch. &#8220;At the end of the day, the courts do have jurisdiction over decisions by the board. So what are they complaining about?&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Like other federal agencies, the NLRB is largely shaped by the current president. Under President Joe Biden, who <a href=\"https:\/\/www.whitehouse.gov\/briefing-room\/statements-releases\/2023\/09\/01\/fact-sheet-ahead-of-labor-day-biden-harris-administration-announces-new-actions-to-empower-workers-building-on-the-presidents-historic-support-for-workers-and-unions\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">refers to himself<\/a> as pro-worker, the NLRB has been <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/legal\/government\/nlrb-paves-way-workers-unionize-without-formal-elections-2023-08-25\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">friendly<\/a> toward workers&#8217; causes. But as the 2024 election looms, a Republican administration could significantly change that, making it more likely for corporations to be successful in attempts to strike down long-standing labor law.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;I do believe that this is a real threat to workers, especially if Donald Trump gets elected,&#8221; Goldstein said.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"SL3FvG7WvY\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/03\/spacex-wrongly-fired-eight-activist-employee-us-labor-board-alleges\/\">SpaceX wrongly fired eight activist employees, US labor board alleges<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;SpaceX wrongly fired eight activist employees, US labor board alleges&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/03\/spacex-wrongly-fired-eight-activist-employee-us-labor-board-alleges\/embed\/#?secret=8o3z5N4pxp#?secret=SL3FvG7WvY\" data-secret=\"SL3FvG7WvY\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2ulUo8Erp1\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/01\/staten-island-amazon-workers-vote-to-unionize\/\">Staten Island Amazon workers vote to unionize<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Staten Island Amazon workers vote to unionize&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/01\/staten-island-amazon-workers-vote-to-unionize\/embed\/#?secret=v5csFgT3F0#?secret=2ulUo8Erp1\" data-secret=\"2ulUo8Erp1\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Amazon alleged in a legal filing published Friday morning that the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) is unconstitutional. SpaceX and Trader Joe&#8217;s &#8212; companies that, like Amazon, have repeatedly\u00a0faced\u00a0labor law violations from the federal agency &#8212; have recently made similar attacks\u00a0that threaten national worker protections. This is just Amazon&#8217;s latest attempt to block union organizing [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574468,"featured_media":1902148,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"4f01d668-6846-3f51-8b0d-3ac549751529","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-16T23:44:50Z","apple_news_api_id":"f0e0e563-6574-4c26-8255-d30abff3110a","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-16T23:44:50Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAD\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/w==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A8ODlY2V0TCaCVdMKv_MRCg","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577065682],"tags":[6602,576930657,576870670,449558953,371748],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>Amazon and SpaceX are quietly trying to demolish national labor law | TechCrunch<\/title>\n<meta name=\"description\" content=\"Amazon alleged in a legal filing published Friday morning that the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) is unconstitutional. /techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/cant-decide-between-bluesky-mastodon-and-nostr-noottis-new-app-lets-you-post-to-all-three\/","title":{"rendered":"Can&#8217;t decide between Bluesky, Mastodon and Nostr? Nootti&#8217;s new app lets you post to all three."},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Managing a social presence these days can be tough. It&#8217;s even tougher for those who are experimenting with the new wave of Twitter-like services, like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/what-is-mastodon\/\">Mastodon<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/nostr.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nostr<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/06\/bluesky-is-now-open-for-anyone-to-join\/\">Bluesky<\/a>, where staying active means a lot of duplicate posts to different networks. Thankfully, developers are starting to address our needs for cross-posting tools. In addition to scheduling services like <a href=\"https:\/\/fedica.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Fedica<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.postpone.app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Postpone<\/a>, there&#8217;s now a new app, <a href=\"https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/pl\/app\/nootti\/id6476751741?platform=iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nootti<\/a>, that allows you to post to Mastodon, Nostr and Bluesky from one interface.<\/p>\n<p>While we&#8217;re still awaiting the launch of multi-service social networking and news trackers,<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/01\/30\/twitterrifics-team-is-back-with-tapestry-an-app-for-tracking-social-media-news-rss-and-more\/\"> like Tapestry<\/a>, Nootti&#8217;s iOS app can at least save you some effort when you want to share a post with your followers across three of the more popular Twitter\/X alternatives. Plus, using Apple&#8217;s native &#8220;Share via&#8230;&#8221; option, you can cross-post that same message to any other apps you choose, like X or Meta&#8217;s Threads. (A clever workaround given <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/instagram-head-says-threads-api-is-in-the-works\/\">Threads&#8217; API<\/a> is not yet open and<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/01\/twitter-to-end-free-access-to-its-api\/\"> X&#8217;s is too expensive<\/a> for indie developers to use.)<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/nootti.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nootti<\/a>, whose name is Finnish for &#8220;note,&#8221; is fairly bare-bones. It won&#8217;t offer all the bells and whistles that come with posting directly on the platforms themselves, like the ability to add polls and alt text on images, or get hashtag suggestions, as on Mastodon. However, if you have a simple text (or text-plus-media) post, Nootti is capable. As you type into the text entry box, Nootti counts how many characters you have left. You can also upload media from your Camera Roll, if you choose, then tap the envelope icon to send the post on its way.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2666863\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2666863\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2666863\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"666\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png 1492w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=150,147 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=300,294 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=768,753 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=680,666 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=1200,1176 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/nootti.png?resize=64,64 64w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2666863\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Nootti<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>To use Nootti, you&#8217;ll first have to configure your accounts in the settings. (Note that you can use an app password for Bluesky, instead of your main password, even though that option isn&#8217;t spelled out in the app.)<\/p>\n<p>What makes Nootti compelling is that you can easily customize each post slightly for the different platforms. To do so, you first type your post in the &#8220;Main&#8221; tab, then switch over to the tabs for the other social networks. The post will be automatically filled in on each tab, but you can edit the message for the individual networks. For instance, you might take a more playful air with your posts on Bluesky, while adding hashtags to your posts on Mastodon. When you hit the envelope icon, the customized set of messages is published to all three networks at once.<\/p>\n<p>Developer Petri Kajander says he built Nootti for himself.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;The current state of social media is defragmentation and, if you just wait, it will not change the status quo. You need to be active to be part of the change,&#8221; he says. &#8220;A lot of people have stopped posting altogether or they are only in one place. This means that you have to extend your presence to multiple places but it takes too much time. Since none of the networks is a clear winner, the best strategy is to post to multiple places, but keep the engagement local to that network and also to customize each post to each platform,&#8221; Kajander adds.<\/p>\n<p>He explains that he doesn&#8217;t believe in auto-posting either, which is why he wanted an app that requires you to write your own posts.<\/p>\n<p>Nootti is a<a href=\"https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/pl\/app\/nootti\/id6476751741?platform=iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> free download on the App Store<\/a>, but Kajander is now developing the paid version, he says, although he hasn&#8217;t yet landed on what revenue model it will use.<\/p>\n<p>Kajander said he also hasn&#8217;t made a decision about supporting other networks, like Threads, or even if that will be required, once it becomes a federated app using the ActivityPub protocol. In the meantime, you can cross-post to any other app with the share button within Nootti instead.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Managing a social presence these days can be tough. It&#8217;s even tougher for those who are experimenting with the new wave of Twitter-like services, like Mastodon, Nostr and Bluesky, where staying active means a lot of duplicate posts to different networks. Thankfully, developers are starting to address our needs for cross-posting tools. In addition to [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2666865,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"d1060d3b-648c-3976-b6e8-b011163bfff2","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-16T22:13:03Z","apple_news_api_id":"89bc2499-a79a-46c0-9e40-53486fabac24","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-16T22:44:45Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AibwkmaeaRsCeQFNIb6usJA","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593],"tags":[449557101,577083484,576943102,577232122,49818],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>Can&#039;t decide between Bluesky, Mastodon and Nostr? TechCrunch","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/social-media\/#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"BreadcrumbList","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/social-media\/#breadcrumb","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"social media"}]},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/49818"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=49818"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666791,"date":"2024-02-16T12:30:52","date_gmt":"2024-02-16T20:30:52","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666791"},"modified":"2024-02-16T14:09:49","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T22:09:49","slug":"video-game-startups-venture-capital-2024","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/video-game-startups-venture-capital-2024\/","title":{"rendered":"Video game startups could be a bright spot for VC in 2024"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The global video game industry makes more money each year than movies and music combined. But that doesn&#8217;t mean the sector was immune to the macroeconomic impacts of the last few years. Gaming companies have held <a href=\"https:\/\/www.gamesindustry.biz\/topics\/layoffs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sizable layoffs<\/a>, and venture funding to the category hit a five-year low in 2023. But VCs are optimistic that things will turn around this year.<\/p>\n<p>Gaming startups raised $2 billion last year, according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.konvoy.vc\/content\/gaming-industry-report-q4-2023\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a report<\/a> from video game-focused VC Konvoy Ventures. 2023\u2019s total was down significantly from 2021, $9.9 billion, and 2022, $6.7 billion.<\/p>\n<p>Many VCs think that 2024 could be a bloodbath for startups, generally, as exits aren&#8217;t likely to return to any kind of normalcy until 2025; many companies will run out of money and have to shut down. But video games might be an outlier, according to some VCs.<\/p>\n<p>For one, there were still a lot of positive milestones for the sector in 2023. There were multiple titles released last year that garnered huge audiences, including <a href=\"https:\/\/gamefaqs.gamespot.com\/boards\/264562-playstation-5\/80617262#:~:text=Turn%20Based%20game%20Baldur's%20Gate,Fantasy%2016%204M%20%2D%20PlayStation%205\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Baldur&#8217;s Gate 3<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fastcompany.com\/91013150\/best-selling-video-game-year-2023-hogwarts-legacy#:~:text='Hogwarts%20Legacy'%20sold%2022%20million,Potter'%20author%2C%20J.K.%20Rowling.&amp;text=When%20it%20comes%20to%20the,t%20much%20of%20a%20contest.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Hogwarts Legacy<\/a>, which each sold more than 22 million copies. Despite a flat year for growth in terms of the overall gaming industry, video games are still projected to grow into a $229 billion industry by the end of the decade.<\/p>\n<p>The category is also changing, which opens the door for startups to launch alongside new trends. As drama around Apple\u2019s App Store fees continues to persist, the industry is moving away from mobile games \u2014 which traditionally raised the most venture money \u2014 and toward cross-platform games, which are more expensive to make, but more lucrative, too. Unlike some categories, AI is just in its early innings in video games and will likely start to stake its place this year.<\/p>\n<p>Josh Chapman, co-founder and managing partner at Konvoy, said the industry should return to normal growth in 2024. The increase in activity caused by tourist investors coming in due to pandemic-fueled gaming spikes and the crypto folks backing web3 gaming has all retreated. The industry can return to organic growth this year, he said.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;A lot of the web3 and crypto stuff in gaming sort of evaporated last year,&#8221; Chapman said. &#8220;The lack of web3 gaming companies pitching in the market led to an overall drop in deal flow. That&#8217;s one subsector of gaming, everything else stayed pretty strong.&#8221;<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Ilya Eremeev, managing and general partner at The Games Fund, told TechCrunch that despite the industry coming off of a more challenging year for fundraising there is a lot to be excited about. One of the main things is the amount of developer talent available after the industry shed thousands in headcount through layoffs last year. Plus, compensation for these positions has gone down, which means startups might be able to land top talent in this market.<\/p>\n<p>While some of the tourist investors have exited the space, corporates have remained active and have started to participate more at the early stages. It also goes against the trends in the broader venture space, where corporate VCs participated in the lowest percentage of U.S. deals in 2023 in nine years, according to PitchBook data.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Strategics in Asia trying to run overseas operations in Europe and in the U.S., especially in Europe, they realized there is a growth opportunity in this region,&#8221; Eremeev said. &#8220;Sometimes they accumulated a lot of capital, they need to invest and are more open for high-risk deals and they invest in early stage.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>But the biggest trend to watch in video games this year is AI. While the AI frenzy in 2022 sparked a lot of existing companies to tout their AI prowess or a lot of companies to start building fast, it wasn&#8217;t as immediate of a jolt to the video game sector, Eremeev said. But companies are starting to launch, and they could have big implications \u2014 especially regarding the costs associated with game creation.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"lwKf0WtHS6\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/this-gaming-startup-tries-to-show-ai-crypto-is-not-a-fad\/\">This gaming startup tries to show &#8216;AI + crypto&#8217; is not a fad<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;This gaming startup tries to show &#8216;AI + crypto&#8217; is not a fad&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/this-gaming-startup-tries-to-show-ai-crypto-is-not-a-fad\/embed\/#?secret=ipoxZvWWBX#?secret=lwKf0WtHS6\" data-secret=\"lwKf0WtHS6\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Mobile ruled the gaming space for a long time, not just because the games were popular, but because they weren&#8217;t as expensive to produce as, say, an immersive data-heavy PC game. This made them more venture-backable. Sofia Dolfe, a partner at Index Ventures focused on gaming, said that watching AI unfold in the video game sector is one of the things she&#8217;s tracking the most this year.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We are at the early innings of AI, it will lower the ability to create something, it will also lower the barrier for some areas of gaming that have been less VC investable,&#8221; Dolfe said. &#8220;Triple AAA quality games on PC that had really long-form creation cycles, it didn&#8217;t lend itself as much with the venture model as mobile games, bringing down those costs we will see a lot of studios being built that leverage that technology that I&#8217;m excited about.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Generative AI embedded in games is another development to watch. There could be really interesting advancements where games can become more of a choose your own adventure in a way if AI allows users to fully control every aspect of the game, including NPCs (non-playable characters). This will of course have to have guardrails and guidelines, Eremeev said.<\/p>\n<p>Interestingly, no investor mentioned AR or VR as an area of growth they are excited about this year. But with the current list of big video game releases set for 2024, and with Disney taking a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/07\/epic-fortnite-disney-entertainment-universe\/\">15% stake in Epic Games<\/a> just last week, VC investors may have good reason to be optimistic about this year and video game startups in the long term.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It&#8217;s going to be a very tricky and challenging year for the gaming industry but some amazing opportunities will emerge,&#8221; Chapman said. &#8220;If you look at Halo, Halo was built in 2001. League of Legends was built in 2009. Tough times produce incredible companies.&#8221;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Video game startups weren&#8217;t immune to recent market pressures, but the industry heads into 2024 on better footing than some sectors.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574554,"featured_media":2666795,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"6715cf77-8267-3e6c-9252-3f15ca2bd107","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-16T20:30:58Z","apple_news_api_id":"6d64a884-38e8-456a-a0b2-c61d7359815d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-16T22:09:38Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AbWSohDjoRWqgssYdc1mBXQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577030456,20429,577030455],"tags":[576879114,449557042,202,1914],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[577037497,577037503,577037507],"yoast_head":"<!-- Threads is running a fact-checking program, but the system isn&#8217;t fully rolled out"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Threads<\/a>, Meta&#8217;s Twitter-like service and competitor to X, may be <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/09\/instagram-and-threads-will-no-longer-proactively-recommend-political-content\/\">distancing itself from politics<\/a>, but that doesn&#8217;t mean it won&#8217;t try to tackle the misinformation that spreads across social media &#8212; particularly in the lead-up to national elections. Following <a href=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@renee.diresta\/post\/C3ZWFf2Ns2j\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">user<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@culturecrave\/post\/C3Z6gi_rJ4S\/?igshid=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reports<\/a> of fact-checks spotted on the network, the company confirmed it&#8217;s engaged with fact-checking organizations to address false information circulating on Threads, but has not fully rolled out direct fact-checking of Threads content as of yet.<\/p>\n<p>Meta had <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2023\/07\/introducing-threads-new-app-text-sharing\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced in December<\/a> that in early 2024 its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/formedia\/mjp\/programs\/third-party-fact-checking\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">fact-checking partners<\/a> would be able to review and rate false content directly on Threads. In the meantime, Meta was only able to match existing fact-checks to &#8220;near-identical content on Threads,&#8221; it said. From the looks of the users&#8217; reports of fact-checking now appearing on Threads, it&#8217;s a case of <em>matched<\/em> ratings, not the more anticipated direct fact-checking of Threads content that people are seeing.<\/p>\n<p>The company confirmed this was the case, telling TechCrunch that it hasn&#8217;t finalized the ability for fact-checkers to rate content directly on Threads yet, but would soon.<\/p>\n<blockquote id=\"ig-tp-C3Z6gi_rJ4S\" class=\"text-post-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border-radius: 16px; max-width: 540px; margin: 1px; min-width: 270px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px); border: 1px solid #00000026;\" data-text-post-permalink=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@culturecrave\/post\/C3Z6gi_rJ4S\" data-text-post-version=\"0\"><p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n<div style=\"padding: 40px; display: flex; flex-direction: column; align-items: center;\">\n<div style=\"display: block; height: 32px; width: 32px; padding-bottom: 20px;\"><\/div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 15px; line-height: 21px; color: #999999; font-weight: 400; padding-bottom: 4px;\">Post by @culturecrave<\/div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 15px; line-height: 21px; color: #000000; font-weight: 600;\">View on Threads<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/embed.js\"><\/script><br \/>\nThreads users <a href=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@renee.diresta\/post\/C3ZWFf2Ns2j\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">had\u00a0noticed that warning labels appeared on posts<\/a> &#8212; in one case, both as an interstitial over a false AI-generated video and as a pop-up that appeared from the bottom of the screen.<\/p>\n<p>The warning message reads &#8220;False Information,&#8221; followed by an explanation that &#8220;the same false information was reviewed in another thread by fact-checkers. There may be small differences.&#8221; It also then noted that &#8220;independent fact-checkers say this information has no basis in fact,&#8221; and documents which fact-checking sources came to this conclusion.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Below this, users can read the name of the fact-checking organizations, and the sources&#8217; conclusion &#8212; e.g. &#8220;False&#8221; &#8212; along with additional information about the content and why it&#8217;s false.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2666740\" style=\"width: 324px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2666740\" class=\"vertical wp-image-2666740 size-large\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?w=314\" alt=\"\" width=\"314\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png 1290w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=69,150 69w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=138,300 138w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=768,1665 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=314,680 314w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=709,1536 709w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=945,2048 945w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=554,1200 554w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8007.png?resize=23,50 23w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 314px) 100vw, 314px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2666740\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Threads screenshot<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>One example of this fact-check can be <a href=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@shayan86bbc\/post\/C3YiAr0t1NG\/?igshid=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">viewed here on Threads<\/a>. It relates to a video that had been circulating in Telegram chats, which claims to be from a France 24 broadcast. However, the video had never aired or even been made &#8212; it was AI-generated, the fact-checking organizations <a href=\"https:\/\/facta.news\/antibufale\/2024\/02\/15\/france24-emmanuel-macron-volodymyr-zelensky-attentato\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">both<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.open.online\/2024\/02\/15\/servizio-france24-ucraina-uccidere-macron-fc\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">state<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>In our tests, the fact-check did initially hide the Threads post with the video but offered a &#8220;See Post&#8221; button to click through and view it. You could optionally tap on &#8220;See why&#8221; if you wanted to know why it was being hidden for false information. The feature feels a bit underdeveloped, however, as the links to fact-checking websites only worked on mobile, not desktop, and the informational warning below the video, once viewed, was in small text that could be easily missed.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2666757\" style=\"width: 310px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2666757\" class=\"wp-image-2666757 size-medium\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/IMG_8008.jpg?w=300\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"300\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2666757\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Threads screenshot<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Though full fact-checking capabilities have not yet rolled out to Threads, when they do the feature will differentiate Threads from its rival X, where fact-checks are now largely managed via crowdsourcing. With X&#8217;s Community Notes (<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/07\/twitter-expands-its-crowdsourced-fact-checking-program-birdwatch-ahead-of-u-s-midterms\/\">originally called Birdwatch<\/a> when the company was known as Twitter), independent volunteers fact-check posts and add additional context or corrections. The system&#8217;s algorithm then attempts to find a consensus among people who don&#8217;t usually share the same views. If both sides agree a fact check is warranted, the Community Note goes live. Meanwhile, the X team can&#8217;t edit or modify the notes, the <a href=\"https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-x\/community-notes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">company&#8217;s website explains<\/a>. Instead, X only takes action on posts that violate its rules, terms or privacy policy.<\/p>\n<p>Elon Musk has championed the use of Community Notes since <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/elon-musk-bought-twitter\/\">acquiring<\/a> the company in 2022, having <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1601059434330890241\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">believed<\/a> that Twitter&#8217;s former team was guilty of left-wing bias and censorship. However, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.propublica.org\/article\/x-verified-accounts-misinformation-israel-hamas-conflict\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a ProPublica report found<\/a> that Community Notes hasn&#8217;t yet sufficiently scaled to address the misinformation circulating on X about the Israel-Hamas war. What&#8217;s more, debunked claims were often spread by Verified accounts with blue checks, giving them higher visibility, it said.<\/p>\n<p>Meta is clearly taking a more cautious approach to news and the potential for misinformation.<\/p>\n<p>Instagram head Adam Mosseri said last year that <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/instagram-head-says-threads-is-not-going-to-amplify-news-on-the-platform\/\">Threads will not &#8220;amplify news&#8221; on its platform<\/a>, upsetting journalists and news consumers who were looking for a Twitter alternative. The company also made good on those promises last week when it announced it would <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/instagram-head-says-threads-is-not-going-to-amplify-news-on-the-platform\/\">no longer proactively surface political content in its recommendations<\/a> across both Threads and Instagram. News and politics may still appear in <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/in-battle-with-x-threads-gets-trending-topics-where-politics-will-be-allowed\/\">the app&#8217;s new trends feature<\/a>, &#8220;today&#8217;s topics,&#8221; however.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Threads, Meta&#8217;s Twitter-like service and competitor to X, may be distancing itself from politics, but that doesn&#8217;t mean it won&#8217;t try to tackle the misinformation that spreads across social media &#8212; particularly in the lead-up to national elections. Following user reports of fact-checks spotted on the network, the company confirmed it&#8217;s engaged with fact-checking organizations [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2570239,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"c41e264c-1e11-3273-9b1d-54fcc6e44ee9","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-16T20:16:36Z","apple_news_api_id":"dd5602d9-cf14-4543-a225-a2aa46cca8ce","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-16T21:44:17Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A3VYC2c8URUOiJaKqRsyozg","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593],"tags":[449557101,449557860,42653521,171,103,398,49818,57505,599182,1700],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!--
