Threads logo on a smartphone"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1700"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1700"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2666774,"date":"2024-02-16T12:14:18","date_gmt":"2024-02-16T20:14:18","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2666774"},"modified":"2024-02-16T12:14:37","modified_gmt":"2024-02-16T20:14:37","slug":"what-we-expect-from-mwc-2024","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/what-we-expect-from-mwc-2024\/","title":{"rendered":"What we expect from MWC 2024"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">In a little<\/span> over a week\u2019s time (February 26-29) around 85,000 or so attendees will descend upon the Fira de Barcelona for Mobile World Congress 2024. Over the past few years, the show has become arguably the most important mobile event of the year. Phone makers, telecoms and a variety of other tech vendors, journalists and analysts converge to discuss what the next year will hold for the industry.<\/p>\n<p>Like every other major in-person event, the last few years have been rocky for MWC. In 2019, the show hit 109,000 visitors &#8212; not quite CES numbers (which hit ~175,000 that same year), but still an impressive turnout for what is ultimately a significantly more narrowly focused show. COVID hit the show hard for a few years (join the club).<\/p>\n<p>After many major vendor withdrawals and weeks of handwringing, the GSM Association (GMA) canceled the 2020 event. A significantly scaled back version of the event happened the following year, with a hard cap on attendance. 2022 saw the beginnings of a bounce back to 60,000 attendees, while last year hit 88,500. Organizers anticipate a similar figure for this year\u2019s event. The number is still down significantly from the show\u2019s height, but MWC still qualifies as a large show.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"75w5cMZMEd\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/techcrunch-is-heading-to-mwc-we-want-to-hear-about-your-startup\/\">TechCrunch is heading to MWC. We want to hear about your startup.<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;TechCrunch is heading to MWC. We want to hear about your startup.&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/techcrunch-is-heading-to-mwc-we-want-to-hear-about-your-startup\/embed\/#?secret=xWjx3SWz3z#?secret=75w5cMZMEd\" data-secret=\"75w5cMZMEd\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>It&#8217;s a good bit harder, however, to judge the show\u2019s current level of importance for the industry. This is due in no small part to some macro trends that have impacted pretty much every tech industry tradeshow. Even prior to the pandemic, large vendors had begun migrating to their own standalone events, so as to not get lost among the noise. COVID only expedited the trend, as companies were forced to figure out live event streaming.<\/p>\n<p>Some of the biggest industry names no longer have a major presence. Take Samsung, which has taken to announcing its new flagships during the once-slow weeks between CES and MWC. As we head into this year\u2019s event, I would love to tell you that &#8212; as with CES &#8212; small, fascinating startups have rushed in to fill that void, but it\u2019s not really the case. At least it\u2019s nowhere near the degree of what we\u2019ve seen from the Vegas event.<\/p>\n<p>There is a decent enough startup presence at MWC, though it takes the form of its own sister event. 4FYN (that\u2019s Four Years From Now) is celebrating its tenth\u00a0year of existence in 2024. Hopefully that will translate into an exciting showing. The event is run by the same organization in the same venue. I\u2019ve come to think of it as the Mobile World Congress equivalent to CES\u2019 Eureka Park: a big, cacophonous room full of startups. There are honestly worst ways to spend an afternoon for work.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>For the companies that participate on the show floor and in pitch-offs, it\u2019s a chance to get an audience with MWC\u2019s large and engaged audience. For us, it\u2019s an opportunity to check out smaller firms that might have otherwise flown under the radar. The event isn\u2019t exclusive to European startups, but they tend to dominate for reasons of proximity. It\u2019s a lot easier to swing over to Spain than it is to fly across an ocean and a continent or two in order to hang out in the neon pit of despair that is Las Vegas, Nevada.<\/p>\n<p>If you\u2019re planning to show off some interesting new tech, let us know <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/techcrunch-is-heading-to-mwc-we-want-to-hear-about-your-startup\/\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Some of the trends I anticipate dominating the conversation include a continued focus on health-centered wearables, including newer form factors like the smart ring. Head-worn displays have always had something of a presence at the show. It seems to be among the bigger shows for HTC Vive, for instance. In the wake of Apple\u2019s Vision Pro launch and Qualcomm\u2019s commitment to AR and VR, I expect to be talking a lot about this once the show kicks off.<\/p>\n<p>MWC is also a fun show for concept devices. This is where Lenovo\/Motorola shine. In fact, the more I think about it, the more I\u2019m convinced that Lenovo is having the most fun among the world\u2019s major consumer electronics manufacturers. Expect everything to fold and\/or slide. Some will be pure concepts, but Lenovo\u2019s not afraid to release some truly, delightfully weird stuff. There\u2019s even a <a href=\"https:\/\/windowsreport.com\/exclusive-lenovo-is-working-on-a-transparent-laptop-might-showcase-it-at-mwc-2024\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u201ctransparent laptop\u201d<\/a> currently rumored for the event.<\/p>\n<p>Speaking of rumors, Nothing\u2019s mid-tier 2a handset is pegged for a March 5\u00a0release (albeit an apparently limited one here in the U.S.). Carl Pei\u2019s old company, OnePlus, will also be present. Last year\u2019s show found the company leaning into its own line of concept devices. This year, meanwhile, it\u2019s rumored to be readying the release of the OnePlus Watch 2.<\/p>\n<p>More broadly speaking, expect AI everywhere at MWC, but be prepared to cut through the BS (don\u2019t worry, we\u2019re here to help). Samsung broke the \u201cgenerative AI smartphone seal with the Galaxy S24 line,\u201d and now it\u2019s going to be out in full form with applications ranging from helpful to ridiculous. I\u2019m cautiously optimistic about the proliferation of AI devices in the mold of the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/humane\/\">Humane<\/a> Pin and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/rabbit\/\">Rabbit R1<\/a>. As with CES, I anticipate robots getting a moment to shine at the event, albeit primarily from European companies this time out. There\u2019s also the matter of that <a href=\"https:\/\/www.mi.com\/global\/discover\/article?id=3095\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Xiaomi car<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Above all, this is a big show for telecos, and yes, the 6G conversations have already begun. Remember before the inevitable deluge, however, that we\u2019re still in the VERY early stage of development. No standard has been agreed upon and we\u2019re likely ~four years out from actually seeing compatible devices. However, 5.5G\/5G advanced is very much a reality being pushed by Chinese firms, in particular. Expect to hear a lot about this &#8212; and other things &#8212; from Huawei, which has spent the last several years slowly clawing its way back up after losing access to Google and Qualcomm products.<\/p>\n<p>Also very real and likely to be very present at this year\u2019s show is Wi-Fi, which succeeds Wi-Fi 6E as the latest wireless standard. TechCrunch will be live and present at MWC, as well.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>In a little over a week\u2019s time (February 26-29) around 85,000 or so attendees will descend upon the Fira de Barcelona for Mobile World Congress 2024. Over the past few years, the show has become arguably the most important mobile event of the year. Phone makers, telecoms and a variety of other tech vendors, journalists [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":699688,"featured_media":2492296,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"e6c6582b-b4fb-30e9-80dc-89585f7ebe69","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2024-02-16T20:14:23Z","apple_news_api_id":"485b25b4-a76f-4109-8cad-14528d0ff97d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2024-02-16T20:14:23Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAD\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/w==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/ASFsltKdvQQmMrRRSjQ_5fQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577052803,449223024],"tags":[257605,577231615],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v20.2.1 (Yoast SEO v20.2.1) - https:\/\/yoast.com\/wordpress\/plugins\/seo\/ -->\n<title>What we expect from MWC 2024 | TechCrunch<\/title>\n<meta name=\"description\" content=\"In a little over a week\u2019s time (February 26-29) around 85,000 or so attendees will descend upon the Fira de Barcelona for Mobile World Congress 2024. He worked for a number of leading tech publications, including Engadget, PCMag, Laptop, and Tech Times, where he served as the Managing Editor. His writing has appeared in Spin, Wired, Playboy, Entertainment Weekly, The Onion, Boing Boing, Publishers Weekly, The Daily Beast and various other publications. He hosts the weekly Boing Boing interview podcast RiYL, has appeared as a regular NPR contributor and shares his Queens apartment with a rabbit named \/16\/poor-people-need-not-apply-for-this-dating-app\/","title":{"rendered":"Poor people need not apply for this dating app"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Welcome to Startups Weekly<\/em><em> \u2014 your weekly recap of everything you can\u2019t miss from the world of startups. <\/em><em>Sign up <\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><em>here<\/em><\/a><em> to get it in your inbox every Friday.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>I\u2019m having one of those weeks where I\u2019m just constantly, very slowly shaking my head at people. As I sat down to read all the stories on TechCrunch and write the Startups Weekly newsletter, well, things didn\u2019t get better.<\/p>\n<p>Just when you thought the dating scene couldn&#8217;t get any more exclusive, along comes Score, the app that says, &#8220;Love is in the air . . . but only if you&#8217;ve got the credit score to breathe it.&#8221; That&#8217;s right, folks, in a world where swiping right could mean finding your soul mate or the next person to ghost you, Score ensures that at least they won&#8217;t be ghosting you due to your bad credit. Launched by a financial platform (of course \u2014 this smells like a marketing stunt), this app is for those who&#8217;ve managed to navigate the treacherous waters of adulting with a half-decent credit. Because nothing says true love like a solid financial report, right? But wait, there&#8217;s a twist! The app is not just exclusive \u2014 it\u2019s temporary. For those who don&#8217;t make the cut? Well, they&#8217;re sent off to financial literacy boot camp, because nothing heals a bruised ego like being told <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/score-is-a-new-dating-app-for-people-with-good-to-excellent-credit\/\">you&#8217;re not financially savvy enough for love<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>America, ladies and gentlemen.<\/p>\n<p>Anyway. <em>Elsewhere<\/em> in the land of unicorns\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0.<\/p>\n<h2>Most interesting startup stories this week<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2191981\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img fetchpriority=\"high\" decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2191981\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2191981\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png\" alt=\"Tesla Autopilot NTSB FSD software\" width=\"1024\" height=\"567\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png 2404w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=150,83 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=768,425 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=680,376 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=1536,850 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=2048,1133 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=1200,664 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-20-at-12.40.05-pm.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2191981\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Tesla<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>In the latest episode of &#8220;How Not to Win Friends and Influence Government Agencies,&#8221; the Dawn Project, a safety advocacy group that&#8217;s been on Tesla&#8217;s case for a while, decided to spice up their Super Bowl ad with an ad that was essentially a call to arms against Tesla&#8217;s Full Self-Driving software. It was meant to be a mic drop. Instead, it turned into a facepalm moment when the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) was like, &#8220;Um, excuse me, we didn&#8217;t sign up for this.&#8221; The NTSB is known for many a thing \u2014 appearances in Super Bowl ads ain\u2019t it, and the org was quick to issue a &#8220;take our seal off your homework&#8221; order to the Dawn Project. They pointed out that the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/dawn-project-tesla-ad-fsd-ntsb\/\">Dawn Project did not have permission to use the seal<\/a>, and its inclusion falsely implied the NTSB&#8217;s endorsement of the campaign. Dramaaaaaaaa.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Oh, but there was plenty more drama where that came from:<\/p>\n<p><strong>Some smoke, some mirrors:<\/strong> Boston Dynamics\u2019s secret sauce is a blend of advanced robotics and marketing genius, served with a side of &#8220;don&#8217;t try this at home&#8221; warnings. But beware, not all that glitters in robot videos is gold: <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/09\/how-to-fake-a-robotics-demo-for-fun-and-profit\/\">Many robot demo videos are bending the truth<\/a> to varying degrees.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Everything is fine, AI promise: <\/strong>In the latest episode of &#8220;AI&#8217;s Musical Chairs,&#8221; Andrej Karpathy, the AI maestro who was one of the founding members of OpenAI, has once again exited the company. No, it&#8217;s not a dramatic soap opera twist or a covert AI uprising; <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/andrej-karpathy-is-leaving-openai-again-but-he-says-there-was-no-drama\/\">Karpathy insists it&#8217;s all smooth sailing, devoid of drama or clandestine plots<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Shut your piehole, AI: <\/strong>The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has officially declared AI-voiced robocalls as the latest public enemy, branding them illegal. If you were looking forward to a personal, albeit fake, call from a presidential candidate or two, you might want to adjust your expectations. The FCC&#8217;s message is clear: <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/08\/fcc-officially-declares-ai-voiced-robocalls-illegal\/\">AI voice clones, you&#8217;re officially on the naughty list<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h2>Most interesting fundraises this week<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2579375\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2579375\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2579375\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg\" alt=\"hands of two people tearing money with flames in the background\" width=\"1024\" height=\"657\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg 2161w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=150,96 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=300,193 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=768,493 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=680,436 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=1536,986 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=2048,1314 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=1200,770 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/GettyImages-10105387.jpg?resize=50,32 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2579375\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Derek Berwin \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>In a twist that&#8217;s got the venture capital world buzzing, Foundry Group, the Boulder-based VC firm known for backing hits like Fitbit and Zynga, is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/foundry-group-is-shutting-down-and-wont-raise-another-fund\/\">hanging up its investment top hat<\/a>. After 18 years and nearly $3.5 billion under management, Foundry has decided its latest $500 million fund, Foundry 2022, will be its swan song. Foundry still plans to lead Series A and B financings with the remaining third of its last fund, but the decision to not raise more funds raises eyebrows and questions about the future for its portfolio companies.<\/p>\n<p>This move follows <a href=\"https:\/\/www.axios.com\/2023\/12\/06\/openview-venture-partners-stops-investing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a similar unexpected announcement from Boston-based OpenView<\/a> at the tail end of last year. Two closures don\u2019t mark a trend, of course, but I\u2019ll bet you billions of dollars to millions of donuts that the TechCrunch team will keep a veeeeeery close eye on this one.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Big raise for banking small companies: <\/strong>Finom, a European challenger bank tailored for SMEs and freelancers, has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/finom-a-european-challenger-bank-for-smes-raises-54m\/\">successfully secured $54 million<\/a> in a Series B funding round. This funding round underscores the growing demand for specialized financial services for SMEs.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Lettuce raise some more money: <\/strong>Indoor farming, once the darling of the startup world with a $3 billion investment influx from 2012 to 2022, is facing a harsh reality check. Companies like AppHarvest and Fifth Season have hit bankruptcy, while others like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/iron-ox-lays-off-50-amounting-to-nearly-half-its-staff\/\">Iron Ox have been forced into layoffs and valuation cuts<\/a>. Despite these challenges, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/hippo-harvest-series-b-fundraise\/\">Hippo Harvest emerges as a beacon of hope<\/a>, securing $21 million in Series B funding.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Well done \u2014 have a cookie: <\/strong>SocialCrowd, a performance management startup, has successfully raised $1.6 million in a pre-seed funding round led by Bread &amp; Butter Ventures. Founded in 2020, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/socialcrowd-raises-1-6m-pre-seed-as-venture-interest-in-work-software-remains-high\/\">SocialCrowd offers a SaaS platform akin to a &#8220;Fitbit for work,&#8221;<\/a> enabling companies to set and reward employee goals.<\/p>\n<h2>This week\u2019s big trend: Hardware<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2659987\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img decoding=\"async\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2659987\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2659987\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"576\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg 4240w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/02\/DSC00027.jpeg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2659987\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Cory Green\/Yahoo<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Okay, fine, so perhaps I\u2019m a little bit biased \u2014 in the past week I\u2019ve changed gears a little, and I\u2019m going to start writing about hardware a bit more again (here\u2019s <a href=\"http:\/\/haje.pub\/cover\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">what I cover and how to pitch me<\/a>). The hardware desk is hella punching above its weight, especially this past week \u2014 there\u2019s a lot of things happening in the business of atoms.<\/p>\n<p>The industrial robotics sector, after enjoying a surge in orders during the pandemic, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/north-american-robot-orders-dropped-30-last-year\">experienced a significant downturn in 2023<\/a>, with orders dropping by nearly one-third, according to the Association for Advancing Automation (A3). This 30% decrease underscores a cooling period for what was once a booming industry, although the decline was not entirely unexpected given the record sales in the preceding years.<\/p>\n<p>More hardware startup nuggets:<\/p>\n<p><strong>Technically, all phones are foldable: <\/strong>And now, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/07\/apple-eyes-a-foldable-iphone-following-vision-pro-launch\/\">Apple is rumored to want to make ones that work <em>after<\/em> you fold them<\/a>. As opposed to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2015\/08\/10\/apple-addresses-bendgate-complaints-with-sturdier-iphone-6s-shell\/\">the last time<\/a> that was happening. We\u2019ve been <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/11\/06\/apple-its-time-to-fold\/\">asking for folding iPhones<\/a> for a while, come to think of it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Dry powder for the big guns: <\/strong>Despite the controversial nature of firearms, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/10\/vcs-are-no-longer-gunshy-about-firearm-startups\/\">Biofire has managed to attract institutional VC backing<\/a>, raising a $7 million round from notable investors. This funding achievement highlights a shift in the venture capital landscape, where deep tech and defense tech startups are increasingly gaining attention.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Open this app with your face: <\/strong>Brian has been doing an extraordinary job covering all things Apple Vision Pro. This week, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/08\/here-are-my-favorite-vision-pro-apps-so-far\/\">he breaks down his favorite apps (so far)<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h2>Other unmissable TechCrunch stories\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0.<\/h2>\n<p>Every week, there\u2019s always a few stories I want to share with you that somehow don\u2019t fit into the categories above. It\u2019d be a shame if you missed \u2019em, so here\u2019s a random grab bag of goodies for ya:<\/p>\n<p><strong>Dirty money, those cleaning fees: <\/strong>Airbnb&#8217;s recent earnings report reveals a significant shift toward more transparent pricing, with nearly 300,000 listings eliminating or reducing cleaning fees. This move, affecting almost 40% of active listings, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/airbnb-is-making-progress-to-get-rid-of-those-hated-cleaning-fees\/\">addresses long-standing customer grievances regarding unexpected costs at checkout<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Notion, but secret-er: <\/strong>Notion recently expanded its suite with <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/09\/notion-acquires-privacy-focused-productivity-platform-skiff\/\">a privacy-centric acquisition, purchasing Skiff<\/a>, a platform known for its end-to-end encrypted file storage, documents, calendar events, and email services.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mozilla hits the brakes: <\/strong>Mozilla, the organization renowned for its Firefox browser, is undergoing significant strategic shifts. The company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/mozilla-downsizes-as-it-refocuses-on-firefox-and-ai-read-the-memo\/\">plans to reduce its investment<\/a> in several products, resulting in layoffs impacting around 60 employees.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Put down the LSD, AI: <\/strong>Oh, the wonders of modern technology, where Google&#8217;s Gemini chatbot, once known as Bard, and Microsoft&#8217;s Copilot are now apparently time travelers. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/11\/googles-and-microsofts-chatbots-are-making-up-super-bowl-stats\/\">Ahead of the 2024 Super Bowl, the bots had stats and results<\/a>, before the game had even started. Whoops.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Burning rubber. And more: <\/strong>A Waymo robotaxi found itself the target of a fiery attack in San Francisco. The incident saw a crowd turn their boredom or perhaps technophobia into an act of vandalism that <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/12\/a-waymo-robotaxi-was-vandalized-and-burned-in-san-francisco\/\">ended with the autonomous vehicle in flames<\/a>. To its credit, it didn\u2019t try to defend itself, so I guess there\u2019s that.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Welcome to Startups Weekly \u2014 your weekly recap of everything you can\u2019t miss from the world of startups. pro"}]},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required echcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/16\/tech-giants-sign-voluntary-pledge-to-fight-election-related-deepfakes\/","title":{"rendered":"Tech giants sign voluntary pledge to fight election-related deepfakes"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Tech companies are pledging to fight election-related deepfakes as policymakers amp up pressure.<\/p>\n<p>Today at the Munich Security Conference, vendors including Microsoft, Meta, Google, Amazon, Adobe and IBM signed an accord signaling their intention to adopt a common framework for responding to AI-generated deepfakes intended to mislead voters. Thirteen other companies, including AI startups OpenAI, Anthropic, Inflection AI, ElevenLabs and Stability AI and social media platforms X (formerly Twitter), TikTok and Snap, joined in signing the accord, along with chipmaker Arm and security firms McAfee and TrendMicro.<\/p>\n<p>The undersigned said they&#8217;ll use methods to detect and label misleading political deepfakes when they&#8217;re created and distributed on their platforms, sharing best practices with one another and providing &#8220;swift and proportionate responses&#8221; when deepfakes start to spread. The companies added that they&#8217;ll pay special attention to context in responding to deepfakes, aiming to &#8220;[safeguard] educational, documentary, artistic, satirical and political expression&#8221; while maintaining transparency with users about their policies on deceptive election content.<\/p>\n<p>The accord is effectively toothless and, some critics may say, amounts to little more than virtue signaling &#8212; its measures are voluntary. But the ballyhooing shows a wariness among the tech sector of regulatory crosshairs as they pertain to elections, in a year when 49% of the world&#8217;s population will head to the polls in national elections.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;There&#8217;s no way the tech sector can protect elections by itself from this new type of electoral abuse,&#8221; Brad Smith, vice chair and president of Microsoft, said in a <a href=\"https:\/\/blogs.microsoft.com\/on-the-issues\/2024\/02\/16\/ai-deepfakes-elections-munich-tech-accord\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">press release<\/a>. &#8220;As we look to the future, it seems to those of us who work at Microsoft that we\u2019ll also need new forms of multistakeholder action &#8230; It&#8217;s abundantly clear that the protection of elections [will require] that we all work together.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>No federal law in the U.S. bans deepfakes, election-related or otherwise. But 10 states around the country have enacted statutes criminalizing them, with Minnesota\u2019s being the first to <a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/deepfake-images-taylor-swift-state-legislation-bffbc274dd178ab054426ee7d691df7e#:~:text=Georgia%2C%20Hawaii%2C%20Texas%20and%20Virginia,targets%20using%20deepfakes%20in%20politics.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/deepfake-images-taylor-swift-state-legislation-bffbc274dd178ab054426ee7d691df7e#:~:text=Georgia%2C%20Hawaii%2C%20Texas%20and%20Virginia,targets%20using%20deepfakes%20in%20politics.\">target<\/a> deepfakes used in political campaigning.<\/p>\n<p>Elsewhere, federal agencies have taken what enforcement action they can to combat the spread of deepfakes.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>This week, the FTC <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/ftc-seeks-to-modify-rule-to-combat-deepfakes\/\">announced<\/a> that it&#8217;s seeking to modify an existing rule that bans the impersonation of businesses or government agencies to cover all consumers, including politicians. And the FCC\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/08\/fcc-officially-declares-ai-voiced-robocalls-illegal\/\">moved<\/a> to make AI-voiced robocalls illegal by reinterpreting a rule that prohibits artificial and prerecorded voice message spam.<\/p>\n<p>In the European Union, the bloc&#8217;s AI Act would require all AI-generated content to be clearly labeled as such. The EU&#8217;s also using its Digital Services Act to force the tech industry to curb deepfakes in various forms.<\/p>\n<p>Deepfakes continue to proliferate, meanwhile. According to data from <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/15\/clarity-raises-16m-to-fight-deepfakes-through-detection\/#:~:text=Be%20that%20as%20it%20may,Ventures%20and%20Flying%20Fish%20Partners.\">Clarity<\/a>, a deepfake detection firm, the number of deepfakes that have been created increased 900% year over year.<\/p>\n<p>Last month, AI robocalls mimicking U.S. President Joe Biden\u2019s voice tried to discourage people from voting in New Hampshire\u2019s primary election. And in November, just days before Slovakia\u2019s elections, AI-generated audio recordings impersonated a liberal candidate discussing plans to raise beer prices and rig the election.<\/p>\n<p>In a recent\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.brennancenter.org\/our-work\/research-reports\/deepfakes-elections-and-shrinking-liars-dividend\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.brennancenter.org\/our-work\/research-reports\/deepfakes-elections-and-shrinking-liars-dividend\">poll<\/a>\u00a0from YouGov, 85% of Americans said they were very concerned or somewhat concerned about the spread of misleading video and audio deepfakes. A separate\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/artificial-intelligence-2024-election-misinformation-poll-8a4c6c07f06914a262ad05b42402ea0e\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/artificial-intelligence-2024-election-misinformation-poll-8a4c6c07f06914a262ad05b42402ea0e\">survey<\/a>\u00a0from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research found that nearly 60% of adults think AI tools will increase the spread of false and misleading information during the 2024 U.S. election cycle.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Tech companies are pledging to fight election-related deepfakes as policymakers amp up pressure. Today at the Munich Security Conference, vendors including Microsoft, Meta, Google, Amazon, Adobe and IBM signed an accord signaling their intention to adopt a common framework for responding to AI-generated deepfakes intended to mislead voters. Thirteen other companies, including AI startups OpenAI, is shutting down in slow motion"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><iframe class=\"embed-iframe\" data-mce-type=\"bookmark\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;\" class=\"mce_SELRES_start\">\ufeff<\/span><\/iframe><\/p>\n<p><em>Listen here or\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/link.chtbl.com\/Equity-010224-Genera\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/link.chtbl.com\/Equity-010224-Genera\">wherever you get your podcasts<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>Hello, and welcome to\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/equity\/id1215439780\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/equity\/id1215439780\">Equity<\/a>, a podcast about the business of startups, where we unpack the numbers and nuance behind the headlines.<\/p>\n<p>We had a power trio on the show today! Mary Ann dropped some hot takes, Karyne jumped back in the saddle and Alex tagged along for the ride. The tech news cycle is up and running at full speed, so we had a mountain of topics to get through. Here&#8217;s the rundown:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Deals of the Week: <\/strong>Rasa&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/rasa-an-enterprise-focused-dev-platform-for-conversational-genai-raises-30m\/\">$30 million Series C<\/a> to build a conversational generative AI product had our tongues wagging. Karyne wanted to talk about the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/this-gaming-startup-tries-to-show-ai-crypto-is-not-a-fad\/\">latest round at the intersection of AI and crypto<\/a>, while Alex <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/hippo-harvest-series-b-fundraise\/\">riffed on Hippo Harvest&#8217;s $21 million fundraise for indoor robot farming<\/a>.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Venture capital&#8217;s year of transition:\u00a0<\/strong>After OpenView called it quits and Countdown Capital returned funds to LPs, it has become clear that venture is evolving. Now, with Foundry saying it is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/13\/foundry-group-is-shutting-down-and-wont-raise-another-fund\/\">not going to raise another fund after its current $500 million vehicle<\/a>, we&#8217;re wondering about the direction venture capital is going to take here on out.<\/li>\n<li><strong>YC&#8217;s new call for startups:<\/strong> Startup accelerator Y Combinator has a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2024\/02\/14\/y-combinator-puts-out-a-new-call-for-startups-in-areas-like-ai-spatial-computing-climate-tech-and-more\/\">new &#8220;request for startups&#8221; list<\/a>. Given the weight that YC carries in startup land, we had to dig into what it&#8217;s proposing. We&#8217;re a little skeptical of the near-term impact of spatial computing, but the other updates made good sense.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<div class=\"article-content\" data-mrf-recirculation=\"In-Article Today is February 16, 2024. My name is Alex, and I&#8217;m joined today by two of my long-running work besties. In one corner, we have senior TechCrunch reporter on the fintech beat, Mary Ann!<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann Azevedo:<\/strong> Hi, Alex. How are you?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> I had really good doughnuts today. So nothing bad will happen whatsoever.<\/p>\n<p>The good news is we have the right people today for this show. On the pod today, the deals of the week are Rasa, Ultraverse, and Hippo Harvest. A little bit of blockchain in there, a little bit of robots, even some fintech. It&#8217;s going to be great.<\/p>\n<p>So for the first theme, we are discussing venture capital\u2019s transitional moment, and why this year is going to look very different from what we have seen in years before. And then we&#8217;re going to close off with what YC wants to see from startups today.<\/p>\n<p>Mary Ann, kick it off with Rasa, which just put together a very nice Series C.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> So I wrote about Rasa this week. As you all know, I generally cover fintech, but with this one, there&#8217;s some fintech involved, because this is a conversational GenAI company that serves financial services companies. And it was interesting to me because, first of all, it&#8217;s been around since 2016. They&#8217;ve been doing this for a while. The startup actually started out as an open source platform for developers to build chatbots, voice apps and other services that would employ conversational AI.<\/p>\n<p>Then a few years ago, they decided to shift toward the enterprise, which seems like a very smart move for the company. They hired a former Oracle executive, Melissa Gordon, as CEO, and now they&#8217;re counting two of the largest banks in the U.S. as customers \u2014 two of the world&#8217;s three top banks, American Express and Deutsche Telekom. So their strategy seems to be paying off. They said their ARR doubled last year.<\/p>\n<p>And now what they&#8217;re doing is, they&#8217;ve developed infrastructure to give developers at these large enterprises the ability to build what they call robust, generative conversational AI assistants that are more human-like and have more personal and meaningful interactions with users.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> So just to kind of boil that down into idiot terms for myself: Essentially, in the world of financial services, a big chunk of the economy, there&#8217;s a lot of conversations. And so what Rasa is doing is building tailored AI chat tech to help companies in that particular niche better interface with customers, right?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> So that when the customer is having the interaction with the bot, you know what it&#8217;s like \u2014 you can usually tell right away, this is a bot, right? But sometimes you actually kind of doubt it, because the bot\u2019s talking to you in a way that feels more human-like, and that&#8217;s what Rasa\u2019s goal is: to make it feel really almost human-like. And Rasa, again, it&#8217;s not building the chatbots directly. It&#8217;s giving these developers at these companies the infrastructure to do it themselves and to kind of more personalize and customize the chat so that they actually have a way to vet potential answers beforehand, things like that.<\/p>\n<p>So something that their chatbot can do is if you ask it to transfer money \u2014 not their chatbot, but a chatbot their technology would help develop. You could transfer money, check balances, and even reset a router in someone&#8217;s house if they&#8217;re having an internet problem. Things like that.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> So, Mary Ann, when I saw this, I had two main thoughts: One, it seems more tailored AI work on a vertical basis makes a lot of sense given that each industry is different. [And] the second thing was \u2014 haven&#8217;t we just talked about this a little bit with Bret Taylor, former co-CEO of Salesforce, [now at Sierra]?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann: <\/strong>So I asked Rasa about that. And what the CTO told me was that it&#8217;s different, because they said Sierra is more of an agent, whereas what Rasa is doing is not building an agent. It&#8217;s more of an LLM- powered chatbot.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> So this is when it gets a little dicey for me, because you said that the Rasa technology will allow them to create things that lets people do things like transfer money, reset their router, okay? Isn&#8217;t that kind of the same pitch that Sierra is making? That these AI agents will help take actions for the end user?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> I think that the end result is the same, but the way they get there is different. That&#8217;s what he&#8217;s saying. But one thing they do have in common is they both claim to be addressing issues like hallucinations, where large language models sometimes make up an answer when it lacks the information to answer accurately. So that is something else they have in common.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne: <\/strong>Yeah, that&#8217;s what I was going to say. Imagine asking it to transfer money and it&#8217;s hallucinating how much money you have or where to transfer it. I don&#8217;t know how much I trust it yet, but at the same time, I also wonder how is this any different than the options that they give you right now? So if you&#8217;re using a chatbot, and it&#8217;s just instead of naturally talking to it, it&#8217;s like, &#8220;Here are three options. Click this button to transfer the money. I wonder why this is any faster or easier than just selecting it yourself rather than having a chatbot do it?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann: <\/strong>I haven&#8217;t used it. So that again, these are all their claims. Two quick asides that I have to point out before I forget. I don&#8217;t think I mentioned that.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> I teed you up with my intro by not saying the dollar amount, like, \u201cThere was a Series C,\u201d and then you&#8217;re like \u201cAI agents.\u201d So I thought we were gonna go backwards.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Yeah, I forgot to mention that they raised $30 million in a Series C round of funding. I&#8217;m gonna go over that tree.\u201d Skilled but scary, says Theresa, our producer. I agree with that.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Right? Anyway, so there&#8217;s a lot of different things related to this company. Part of the problem, I think, is we&#8217;re seeing so many startups using AI, claiming they are AI-powered, building AI stuff. It is getting harder and harder to differentiate them and tell them apart, so I can understand why you would have these kinds of questions.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> We need better definitions for AI agents versus conversational AI bots. And I wonder if there are these distinctions without major differences, or if there are big differences and we&#8217;re simply missing the point. I think, probably in six months, we&#8217;ll all know the answer to that. But right now, it still feels a bit nascent. Not a fad, though, I don&#8217;t think this AI business [is a fad]. Everyone wants to save money on customer support costs, so expect more of this. But a place where there might be a fad, Karyne, is apparently the world of AI and crypto.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> Yeah, so just this week, there was a company called Ultiverse. It&#8217;s based in Singapore, and they raised $4 million at a $150 million valuation led by IDG Capital, which has invested in other Chinese gaming brands, like Tencent, and Xiaomi, as well as crypto upstarts like Coinbase and Circle. And what Ultiverse does is it blends AI and crypto gaming, or blockchain gaming. And so I think the fad is the crypto gaming components, but maybe also the AI component. So it&#8217;s an AI-powered platform for crypto game production and publishing. So they publish their own games, but then they can have other companies build games on their platform. And so they&#8217;re using LLMs that already exist, like GPT-4, Llama and Stable Diffusion to train in-game, nonplayable characters, which I think is maybe the best use case for AI that I have heard of within the gaming community yet. And I will say that I&#8217;m a gamer, but not these types of games. So I&#8217;m not quite sure about blockchain gaming as a whole.<\/p>\n<p>But a bunch of people are playing this. They have a mobile cricket game that has about 200,000 Unique Active wallet addresses across all of their games. Right now, the monthly active users are about 830,000 people. Most of the people who are playing the cricket game are non-crypto users. So the game uses something called account abstraction, which means that even people who aren&#8217;t spun up on crypto-related things can play and then get paid out. But I think the main component here is the AI features that they&#8217;re trying to help introduce and trying to get others to use on their platform. (laughs) Tell me more.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> I&#8217;m a little skeptical of parts of this. That&#8217;s not to be rude because I do think that trying to bridge different nascent technologies or rapidly emerging technologies is a cool thing that could yield at the intersection of them \u2014 in this case, AI and crypto \u2014 something special. I also agree that the use of modern AI tools like LLMs inside of video games is super awesome, because then you can have more than three dialogue options. Of course, there&#8217;s voice acting and stuff to be considered there, but it&#8217;s possible to do cool things, especially with text. Huge fan. And crypto gaming to me \u2014 people like to speculate; they like to trade, like to invest. Okay, cool. It&#8217;s just when you smush them together, I get a little weird.<\/p>\n<p>So I was on the Ultiverse website and I was poking through their material on Terminus, which is \u201ca decentralized virtual Metaverse platform that&#8217;s built on both the BNB chain,\u201d so Binance\u2019s chain, \u201cand Unreal Engine 5.\u201d And it just feels like a MMORPG-ish thing with some crypto crap slugged onto it. I just don&#8217;t want an NFC gallery in my game. I want to be left alone. And so that&#8217;s what I kind of struggle with. Maybe I&#8217;m just an old man shouting at a cloud. But that&#8217;s my advice.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> I mean, I&#8217;ll be honest. But my first thought is, it feels kind of gimmicky. And that could just be me talking out of my you know what. But in the company&#8217;s defense is that they use account abstraction, so that even if you&#8217;re not well-versed in crypto or have crypto knowledge, you can still play and it could still be fun. I just don&#8217;t know how many other games out there might be like this. I mean, are there other AI-powered games? Or you know, is this just the beginning of a trend, or what? I don\u2019t know. Are we going to see more of this?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> People hope it\u2019s a trend. People want it to be a trend, because they think crypto is the future. And so, to me, there&#8217;s a religious viewpoint here that, like, if you believe blockchains are the future, then you need to bring AI to them or vice versa, because they&#8217;re both the future. So the future has to come together.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne: <\/strong>Yeah, I think one of the most famous, maybe infamous, examples of a blockchain game and a crypto game gone wrong was the Axie Infinity debacle, where people were just scammed out of money and had to farm for coins or whatever was going on there. And so the implication of when you think of a blockchain game, you&#8217;re like, \u201cOh, great. It&#8217;s a scam.\u201d I think this is based on an article that was written last month by one of Ethereum\u2019s co-founders that is called \u201cAI + Crypto.\u201d And his points were that AI could really be used in crypto gaming in four different ways \u2014 with non-playable characters, you could use AI to judge the results of a game, or their various other applications. And so here is one way that they&#8217;re doing it, and in this case, they&#8217;re using AI to really speed up the production of the game. And it just happens to be a blockchain game on top of it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> There are so many ways to approach gaming as a model. There are companies that produce free-to-play games that have in-app monetization. Even some new games like Stormgate, an RTS [real-time strategy], is approaching it that way. Very cool. There&#8217;s MMORPGs [massive multiplayer online role-playing games] that have subscription-based economics. There&#8217;s indie publishers that sell games for a discrete price and then also upsell you on the soundtrack. Then there&#8217;s the Paradox model, in which you make a game and then add DLCs [downloadable content] to expand the content over time. All of these models work for different types of titles, and I can see a place where AI fits into, essentially, all of them in time. Crypto gaming seems to always have an NFT gallery and some speculative currency, and people trying to grind out extra money.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> Yes.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex: <\/strong>And until blockchain brings something that isn&#8217;t that, I don&#8217;t care about it. When blockchain makes my games that exist already better; when it makes a better grand strategy game, a better city management game, a better RPG, then I&#8217;m here for it. But I don&#8217;t want fucking NFTs.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Yeah, I&#8217;m having flashbacks to like two years ago because you know how I feel about NFTs.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex: <\/strong>Since we&#8217;re here now, I&#8217;m going to talk more about this. So, on the Ultiverse website, there&#8217;s this little thing about \u201cAre you ready to meet your meta GF or meta BFF?\u201d And it was this two-week long moonlight NFT mint, so I went on OpenSea and I looked it up. And it&#8217;s just like one woman&#8217;s head with different characteristics attached to her, and some of them are rare. I don&#8217;t know, is this what we&#8217;ve managed to accomplish in all these years of crypto? It just feels a little bit modest compared to the progress we&#8217;re seeing elsewhere in the world of technology.<\/p>\n<p>And that brings me to robots! Everyone&#8217;s favorite segment. My deal of the week is Hippo Harvest. They just raised a $21 million Series B. Tim De Chant had this for us as a TechCrunch exclusive. The company raised the money from Standard Investments, Congress Ventures, Amazon Climate Pledge Fund, Hawthorne Food Ventures, and Energy Impact Partners. The company is now worth $145 million, and it&#8217;s going to use small robots to run indoor farms, and it thinks it can do this much more efficiently \u2014 cut back on water usage, fertilizer usage. You know, I think we&#8217;ve all become accustomed to the idea of warehouses using cute little \u2019bots to zip around and move things. Why not use those same now-commoditized robots to grow lettuce and other goods? So I think this is awesome. But, Mary Ann, you are our skeptic-in-chief, so I want to know: What do you think?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> I agree, I think it&#8217;s cool. Really, really cool, actually. They said that they can grow the greens using up to 92% less water \u2014 that&#8217;s huge! Thirty-five percent less fertilizer and no pesticides! So if it works, why not? This is great! So they want to stick with greenhouses rather than vertical farms. I guess, the angle of this is, it\u2019s more of a robot startup really than just indoor farming. This sector has struggled. We&#8217;ve seen a few players in this space for bankruptcy \u2014 AppHarvest, Fifth Season. Iron Ox had some layoffs, and Bowery Farming, which was booming a few years ago, also had some layoffs and valuation cuts. But this feels like it&#8217;s a little different. It has real potential, from my humble perspective.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> I have a question, though: Is this going to drive up the costs of, let\u2019s say, lettuce? Because aren&#8217;t robots expensive to use?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Well, commoditized robots are less so. So if you&#8217;re Amazon, and you&#8217;re gonna have \u2014 I&#8217;m gonna make up a number here \u2014 1,000 warehouses across the United States [whispers, &#8220;That&#8217;s not the right number&#8221;]. You&#8217;re going to have a bunch of robots inside those warehouses. And when you start thinking about robots in the hundreds of thousands or millions of units, the costs are going to come down quite a lot. You&#8217;re going to figure out a way to build them.<\/p>\n<p>And so the idea here is take that commoditized tech and then apply it to the struggling area of indoor or vertical farming. And so the  to your point, Karyne, is not only can those units be cheap enough to make this work when you purchase them, but also then to run and maintain them. And that&#8217;s going to be the gambit. But on the price point, here&#8217;s my pitch to you: Karyne, you&#8217;re at the store and you&#8217;re going to make your beautiful child a lovely salad for dinner because he&#8217;s a growing boy and needs to eat greens. And you&#8217;re staring down three lettuce options. The cheap version, which has no marks about where it was grown, how it was grown, etc. Then there&#8217;s an organic-ish version \u2014 you know, the lettuce was patted on the head and sung songs and so forth. And then there&#8217;s a third option: This was grown indoors; it saved water. If you buy this lettuce, you&#8217;re helping the planet. How much more would you pay for option three and option two?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> Well, I&#8217;m from the Bay Area, so you know I&#8217;m going to go for the most woo lettuce that exists on the shelf. So I will go for the one that did. And being in California, we&#8217;re one drought away from being cut off from the rest of the country. I get it. And that makes sense. And I would pay a little bit more for that, I suppose. But with food scarcity, urban farming is trying to become a thing. I&#8217;m here for it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> I mean, one thing I&#8217;d argue is that when we talk about food scarcity, and people being priced out of the standard goods of life, one thing you could also say, and this is not a positive, but maybe food is actually too cheap in terms of its impact on the planet, and we&#8217;re just pushing some cost to the future and not dealing with the now because just economically, it\u2019s [easier] to do it this way. Hippo Harvest, I hope it does really well. I love this. I&#8217;ve always thought that urban farming makes a lot of sense \u2014 shipping stuff across rail lines is pretty efficient, but if you put it into a truck, it&#8217;s not. So I&#8217;m really into this. And also I don&#8217;t like farming. So let the robots do it. That&#8217;s just hard, not into it.<\/p>\n<p>Now, when we come back, my friends, we&#8217;re talking about some big ventures\u2019 comings and goings. Mary Ann has all you need to know. We\u2019ll be right back after this short break.<\/p>\n<p><strong>[AD]<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> So this week, I wrote about the Foundry Group. This is a venture capital firm that&#8217;s been around for 18 years and done a lot of investing. Apparently it has a very impressive exit record: Some companies in their portfolio are Fitbit, Zynga, and AvidXchange. And the big news was they&#8217;ve decided to wind down operations and not raise any more funds.<\/p>\n<p>So this was a little unexpected to most of us, because the firm just announced a $500 million fund last May. Now, after I published the story, I had a lot of people cry out on Twitter that this was not unexpected. Everybody knew that this was the plan all along. Maybe you knew it if you were another venture capitalist and had talked to Seth Levine, for example, one of the co-founders and partners, and heard him tell you. Because apparently he had talked about his plans, which started to brew in his mind sometime in 2023, that he may decide not to invest anymore, and that turned into the fund deciding to wind down.<\/p>\n<p>But anyway, most of us did not know about this, so it was generally unexpected. And they wouldn&#8217;t talk to me directly about the decision, but I did get pointed to some blogs, and apparently they said that, yes, this is unusual, and VC firms rarely make decisions like this. But it&#8217;s something that they planned to do when they started back in 2006 \u2014 they decided not to build a legacy or generational firm; they wanted to focus just on the work of investing. And then they . . . kept saying, \u201cIs this going to be our last one? Is this going to be our last one?\u201d And they decided not to raise another one. So that&#8217;s basically it.<\/p>\n<p>But to be clear, when we say they&#8217;re shutting down or winding down, that doesn&#8217;t mean their doors are closed or they&#8217;re not doing anything. That&#8217;s not the case at all here unlike OpenView, which I think was in December or January \u2014 I lose track now \u2014 it did actually shut down and lay off partners. Foundry still has 33% to 40% left out of its $500 million fund to invest. So it&#8217;s planning to still continue to lead Series A and B financings out of that fund. The company says it will also continue to work with businesses in which it has investments for years to come.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> And that&#8217;s the critical thing. There&#8217;s two ways to shutter a business. One is to just close your doors, lock it and run away, and the other is to wind down new operations and then support what you have already in the market. For VCs, the product is investment, so they&#8217;re shutting down kind of in slow motion. This will slowly degrade in terms of total activity until it reaches zero at a point down the road.<\/p>\n<p>But here&#8217;s my thing. Mary Ann, I watched you get dragged on Twitter for this. And two things piss me off. Part of our job is to go into the weeds and pull things up so people can see them who didn&#8217;t already know that they were there. So simply because you, an insider in the VC world whose friends are VCs and founders, knew this does not mean that the TechCrunch audience did. A lot of people read TechCrunch, and there&#8217;s not that many VCs out there. And then also you didn&#8217;t get it wrong. I didn&#8217;t like it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Well, thank you for defending me, Alex. It was a very fact-based article. I had no malicious intentions, no hidden agenda. But I will say I was touched and impressed by the number of people who rushed to defend Foundry. The firm clearly has a lot of supporters and fans and portfolio companies, other VCs, or general observers. And to me that says a lot about the firm and the character of the partners. So I was very impressed by that. Yes, I was actually pretty touched by that, to be honest with you.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> There is a way, though, to show respect without crapping on someone else. I would like to point that out.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> So .\u00a0.\u00a0. if the firm was happy with the reporting, then who cares about the haters? And they seemed comfortable with the language used. But anyway, overall, it was a big deal in the venture world. This is a firm that\u2019s been around for a long time \u2014 almost two decades \u2014 had made over 200 investments, and had a really great reputation [and] it seems like .\u00a0.\u00a0. a lot of exits. So they were prolific investors and well-regarded ones. So it is a loss for the venture world. So that is news.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> But think about how long a venture fund lasts, right? I mean, we used to think of these as 10-year instruments? Now they&#8217;re more like 12. And so you know, get piles of money and you&#8217;re doing a big fund, and maybe you&#8217;re looking around and thinking to yourself, \u201cWhat if I opened my long-hoped-for miniature golf course-cum-personal bar\/indoor farm that I&#8217;ve always wanted to on my property. I don&#8217;t want to do 12 more years of work?\u201d I kind of get it. I mean, if I had one-tenth of the money of these partners, I would not be working. So I don&#8217;t know, it&#8217;s weird to see a firm shut down. But on a personal basis, I get it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> I do, too. I totally get it. So I think we just have to be careful to understand that this sounds like apparently a thought-out decision. It isn&#8217;t one where it feels like in the case of OpenView, [which] really kind of was very abrupt, shutting down and having to lay off people. They seem to be two very different cases. But what we are seeing overall, and what I keep hearing from others is that the venture world is shrinking. And regardless of what the reasons are, there are a lot of firms that seem to be either scaling back, winding down, cutting staff. So it&#8217;s an overall, and I hate to use the word \u201ctrend,\u201d but this is something we&#8217;re probably going to be seeing more of in different forms.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex: <\/strong>Yeah, but there&#8217;s some good news out there as well, Karyne, for both Earlybird Health and Homebrew. What&#8217;s going on there?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> I mean, it looks like they are growing. So you know, even within the shrinking of all the firms that we talked about, there are a few that are still growing up and down.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Yeah. Earlybird Health is a Europe-focused health tech fund, and they doubled essentially from Fund I to Fund II. If memory serves, I think they put together like \u20ac175 million for their new fund. And then Homebrew, which is mostly now working with Partner Capital, is putting together a $50 million fund that we don&#8217;t quite understand yet, Mary Ann, I don&#8217;t think? But the gist is, from our guess, it&#8217;s probably an opportunity fund or something similar along those lines.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Yeah, exactly. From what I understand, what I heard is that they didn&#8217;t want to use SPVs anymore for follow-on, pro rata investments. So they are targeting this new fund.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Mary Ann, I knew exactly what you just said, but not everybody has been so enmeshed in venture things. So SPVs are special purpose vehicles. Essentially, it&#8217;s like a micro venture capital fund you put together for a single deal. Let&#8217;s say you have allocation but don&#8217;t have enough capital. You can put together an SPV, raise some more money and put that in. It&#8217;s a single check. Pro rata rights essentially allow a prior investor to defend their current percentage ownership in a company over time. They need to put in more capital for that, usually at higher prices. Pro rata rights are a big deal in venture land, both in terms of how people use them or abuse them. And I think that should cover it.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Thank you, Alex. You&#8217;re so good. Like putting things in everyday language.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Well, Mary Ann, isn&#8217;t that what we do all day?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann: <\/strong>You know, it is what we&#8217;re supposed to do.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex: <\/strong>All right. Yeah. Well, wait till you see the post I wrote with Ron. It&#8217;s full of complete jargon, and I can&#8217;t wait to get it down. All right, Karyne: I want to talk about Y Combinator, everyone&#8217;s favorite, or least favorite accelerator. Controversial, certainly. At times, very popular and very successful. And they have a new call for startups out there. Walk us through what they&#8217;re looking for.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> So they are putting out a call for startups in areas like AI, spatial computing, climate tech, and health tech, among other things. I don&#8217;t think that the AI and spatial computing aspects of their list are very surprising considering that AI is hot, hot, hot, and Apple&#8217;s Vision Pro just came out, and so they are expecting a lot of startups to be working on spatial computing-type apps, I suppose?<\/p>\n<p>They haven&#8217;t done a request like this since 2018. Of course, they updated the list a little bit during the pandemic, when they were looking for COVID-related startups. Healthcare startups are still on their list, but this time they&#8217;re focusing on cancer treatment, and other kinds of help in the healthcare industry, such as eliminating the middleman when it comes to certain aspects of healthcare.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Mary Ann, I&#8217;m curious. The Vision Pro is out, and some people have bought it. It got some good reviews, some mixed reviews. Do you think that&#8217;s gonna be a big enough niche to launch startups on top of in the coming years?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> That&#8217;s a good question. I don&#8217;t know. Like, how about with Meta\u2019s? Did startups launch off its comparable device? Because I don&#8217;t know.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> I don\u2019t think in this way.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Yeah, not like this. I mean, there are some games that have been made that are VR-compatible, that I presume work with Quest headsets. But no, not like the similar boom we saw with the launch of the App Store for iOS, for example, which did lead to generations of new companies. I just think it&#8217;s still too small, the space. Like Microsoft tried this with HoloLens. Name a company that built a killer HoloLens app. Silence.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> I would agree. I mean, I was a little surprised to see that as one of its main areas of focus. Of course, obviously, climate tech and applications of AI were not surprising. But yeah, I thought it was interesting, too, that this is the first time they&#8217;ve done this really since 2018, except as Karyne mentioned, when COVID hit. So I&#8217;m just wondering, what drove them to start this back up again?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Well, I mean, gosh, I feel like we&#8217;ve almost gotten done digesting, at last, the excesses of 2021. And so maybe after you finally finish your heartburn and indigestion, you begin to kind of look at the menu again. And then this analogy started for cheeseburgers.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Mary Ann:<\/strong> Yeah, maybe it wants to be more targeted now and hoping to entice startups in these areas. Not that it&#8217;s trying to deter startups that aren&#8217;t doing these things, but I guess it just wants to be more targeted in its approach, and then who applies for its cohorts.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> Okay, I&#8217;m gonna throw in somebody else here, because I think we should broaden our context. If Tim, our resident climate genius, was here, he would mention things like the Inflation Reduction Act, changes to green energy financing. And I&#8217;m saying climate words. Trees. Things like that, Tim would talk about those. So I think there has been a top-down national shift and focus toward more climate tech that could unlock spending from both governments and private corporations. So climate tech, as a new theme for YC, kind of fits in there for me.<\/p>\n<p>And then defense technology has certainly become much less disliked in venture circles \u2014 guns used to be kind of under a vice clause, but now people want to make really big guns and sell them to the government. Cool, fair enough. And then space. I really think that now the space costs have come down so much on a launch basis, especially with shared launches and larger rockets coming from SpaceX, there&#8217;s a lot more stuff you can do there. And this week, just because I wanted to bring it up somewhere, Varda Space, which makes drugs in space, because there&#8217;s less gravity so you can do cool stuff. Got permission to bring them back! So we&#8217;re soon gonna have space drugs on the market. So I think this YC list makes a lot of sense. I mean, look, they&#8217;re kind of dissing crypto a little bit, but I\u2019m not shocked.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Karyne:<\/strong> And maybe that&#8217;s fine. And I don&#8217;t remember where I read this, but when they were creating this list, they&#8217;re thinking of it as like a conversation starter, like a prompt for people who are working on something and don&#8217;t know quite yet where it&#8217;ll fit in the market. This could be directionally helpful for them. Yeah, I&#8217;m really looking forward to Demo Day as well. When is Demo Day?<\/p>\n<p><strong>Alex:<\/strong> I think it&#8217;s April 3 or April 4. So coming up. And of course, we are going to have all things Demo Day on this show. Sometimes we even do an extra episode just to dig into the coolest companies that we saw. So Mary Ann, Karyne and I will be bringing you that very soon.<\/p>\n<p>But that&#8217;s all the time we have for today. Equity comes out three times a week: on Mondays, on Wednesdays, and on Fridays. And if you&#8217;re a social person, come socialize with us, because we are @equitypod on X and Threads, and we are @techcrunchpod on TikTok. All right, bye, everybody. Talk to you soon!<\/p>\n<p>Equity is hosted by myself, Alex Wilhelm, and TechCrunch senior reporter, Mary Ann Azevedo. We are produced by Theresa Loconsolo, with editing by Kell. Bryce Durbin is our illustrator. A big thank-you to the audience development team, and Henry Pickavet, who manages TechCrunch audio products.<\/p>\n<p>Thank you so much for listening, and we&#8217;ll talk to you next time.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The Equity crew is highlighting deals of As co-CEO, Tekedra is responsible for overall company strategy, with her primary focus on ensuring Waymo\u2019s transformational technology \u2014 the Waymo Driver \u2014 is commercialized and widely adopted. Tekedra has more than two decades of experience advising consumer technology companies on how to advance their business interests around the world and is an expert in navigating complex high-profile issues. She began her career working with regulated technology and telecom industries, and leading global technology transactions. She has served as a trusted advisor to CEOs managing growth and risk-mitigation strategies. Tekedra previously served as COO of Waymo. Prior to Waymo, Tekedra led global teams across five continents at eBay, Yahoo, AOL and Startec. She started her career at the DC-based law firm Steptoe &amp; Johnson LLP. Tekedra currently serves on the Board of Directors for Intuit, and on the Advisory Council for Boom Technology. She is a social impact-focused angel investor, and an Advisor and LP with the Operator Collective. She has been recognized by Automotive News in 2020 as among the 100 Leading Women in the North American Auto Industry, \u201cTop 20 in 2020 Influential Women in Mobility\u201d by Vulog, and as one of the most influential black leaders in corporate America by Savoy magazine in 2020 and 2019. She has over 17 years of experience in tech, spanning industry, academia, and government. Before joining Signal as President, she was the Minderoo Research Professor at NYU, and served as the Faculty Director of the AI Now Institute which she co-founded. Her research and scholarly work helped shape global AI policy and shift the public narrative on AI to better recognize the surveillance business practices and concentration of industrial resources that modern AI requires. Prior to NYU, she worked at Google for over a decade, where she led product and engineering teams, founded Google\u2019s Open Research Group, and co-founded M-Lab, a globally distributed network measurement platform that now provides the world\u2019s largest source of open data on internet performance. She also helped lead organizing at Google. She was one of the core organizers pushing back against the company\u2019s insufficient response to concerns about AI and its harms, and was a central organizer of the Google Walkout. She has advised the White House, the FCC, the City of New York, the European Parliament, and many other governments and civil society organizations on privacy, security, artificial intelligence, internet policy, and measurement. A two-time YC alumni, Jesse founded Raven Tech in 2013 and built a natural language-powered operating system that was later deployed into one of the best-selling smart speakers. The form factors and software designs are still used as some of the industry standards today. April","sessions":[{"guid":"133574568657b418d9dda7","start":"10:00 am","end":"10:35 am","description":"Incubators and accelerators often provide support structures for early-stage startups. For founders transitioning from academia, specific programs are often tailored to their unique needs, as these founders often seek assistance in defining the potential commercial viability of their research. Academia-sourced founders face unique challenges departing from institutions of higher education and national labs. Selecting the right startup program can help ensure that young companies seamlessly navigate known hurdles post-formation. Here\u2019s what you need to know today.","title":"Selecting the Right Accelerator or Incubator","videoUrl":"","sessionTypeId":false,"speakers":[{"name":"Emily Knight","uuid":"1cf098da27c1edaedcb05b6d663ad8101702574476","cb_tag":0}],"sponsors":[],"tags":[]},{"guid":"13357454665cbc9b672573","start":"10:00 am","end":"10:30 am","description":"In the dynamic world of startups, the ability to adapt is not just an asset; it&#8217;s a necessity. &#8220;Adapt &amp; Thrive: Mastering the Chameleon Mindset&#8221; is a deep dive into the art of audience adaptation, a crucial skill for entrepreneurs who aim to connect with a diverse customer base effectively. This session explores strategies for actively listening to and learning from customer feedback, enabling startups to understand their audience&#8217;s evolving needs deeply. We&#8217;ll discuss how to use these insights to make informed decisions about when to pivot or tweak your business model to better serve your market. Attendees will learn practical techniques for identifying signs that indicate a need for change, ways to test new approaches without losing sight of their core mission, and how to communicate these shifts to stakeholders.
